If i'm gonna be honest, Some of my favourite games of all time include Rome Total War, AoE 2, Just Cause 2, Rimworld, Mount and Blade And MEN OF WAR ASSAULT SQUAD 2.
It is a masterpiece in real time strategy, the detail of cover, the unique aspects of the units. 
Now i don't play the singleplayer... really ever, All my hours are in MP or Co op. And it's fantastic, a game i can always come back to and have a blast.
It's a shame the MP has died down a little down and i do think it is time for a new addition to the franchise, but you bet, i will be getting on that straight away!

It's a nice game to say at least. With all the cool mechanics inherited from the previous versions, and also a much more developed operating system, this game should have been one of my favorite real time strategy games. However, when I came down to the real playing part, I always found it(the vanilla) disappointed me a lot. The campaign is nonsense, all of 6 different campaign sections, without any story line or lore, share the same mission design, making the single player part vague and boring. Then I turned to LAN, I honestly didn't have a hard time fighting with actual players, but I just never find it funny to win without any modes or addons. However hard I manage to beat them, I just feel like the process always being a pain in the butt. 

That's everything about my own experience about the base game so far. My suggestion is NOT to touch vanilla anyway. If you want to, don't even buy any of their DLCs. The Workshop will have all the fun you need. They have missions for single & coop, and also tons of fantastic mods for PVP and mission packs. There will be more crashes, but that's just workshops are meant to be.

The greatest game ever made. 
The greatest top-down-view, direct control, WW2 rts strategy game-play style ever made. 

The current version is not-playable / not enjoyable for me since Patch 7 September 2014. 
The sound engine was really f fuck ed-up ! by the Gem engine developers, DMS indie game developers or by the sound engine maker Miles. 

They ruined basic stereo in a game for 1st time ever in the series since Faces of War. 
Stereo separation sounds like it is set too wide for starters. 
You have to put the game onto 5.1 to get close to correct stereo image with headphones & they added a stupid distance sound filter that muffles the sounds artificially which sounds s hit !

But lucky I was able keep playing a patch 6 version with superior stereo because it would have been un-playable as it is today, 4 years later.  

I have a quality gaming desktop computer, high quality headphones & 
appreciation of sounds & graphics. 

I have been playing this series since Faces of War.
Faces of War demo won the play prize over that stupid Company of Heroes arcadish junk.
Next came Men of War, MoW Assault Squad then MoW Assault Squad 2.

For Men of War Assault Squad 3 they could upgrade it to 64 bit, fix the sound engine to correct stereo, fix those stupid skinny soldier models since one of the last patches, improve all the old tank & unit models & environments textures & graphics & sounds to current high digital standards. 

This game could be made perfect. 

I only play single player. This is the only game I play & enjoy. 
I still play the same battles that come with the game. They never play-out exactly the same, + there are many extra mission mods in the Workshop. 

I would ONLY recommend the current version of this game for gamers that don't care or are dumb when it comes to sound quality & would only use a laptop & it's crappy speakers.

Almost every RTS that i can think of has custom battles against bots in the base game, and i find it disgusting that the developers think it's ok to nickel and dime you ten dollars for the airborne DLC which includes them. If you are fan of WW2 games, and wish for some good old RTS experience, then this game is for you. The great thing about this game is that you can complete missions anyway you want, and you can use anything to your advantage like: Destroying buildings to block enemy, or make it fall on him. Use trees to put your snipers on, call in artillery, direct control system, huge loads of weapons for your infantry units, and a load of vehicles to play with. The other great thing is the mod support, and you have a f**k ton of mods to play around with if you wish for more weapons, vehicles, or extra challenge. While we are on mod subject, it is nice to see people who have re- created missions from our favourite good old games like: Call of Duty, Medal of Honor, Battlefield etc. I suggest this game to anyone, if you are still having doubts it's alright, at first it didn't seem appealing to me, but i gave it a try and you should too.

This game looks and sounds like it came out in the early 2000s but don't let that fool you. This is easily one of the most innovative and impressive RTS games to ever grace the PC world. With a fleshed out armor/penetration system, modular damage, an inventory/scavenging system, a very impressive physics engine, an active (and *extremely* talented) modding community, and the ability to directly control individual units on the battlefield a la third-person-shooters; MoW2 goes so much further than just being a simple WW2 RTS. Find me any other RTS that allows me to assume direct control of a tank in order to fire THROUGH a building and ammo rack an enemy tank on the other side, causing it to detonate and roll a half-track next to it. These moments are what make MoW2 worth every penny.

Lack of decent tutorial which would cover what various indicators, icons and buttons mean (as well as lack of simple captions next to those buttons) makes the game absolutely annoying at the start. Without clear explanations of basic game mechanics the first singleplayer campaign is pure torment -- controls are unresponsive, units split and merge into squads chaotically, and battlefield feels like headache-inducing mess.
But once some time is spent, it appears to be enjoyable, you get used to flaws of UI, find some buttons that help make your orders more clear, find out how to use direct control, and it starts to seem playable. Taking into consideration that I am still playing singleplayer campaigns on easy mode, it will require few more dozens of hours to learn to play the game just fine, but I honestly not sure if I want this.

[i]Men of War: Assault Squad 2[/i] takes the amazing micro-intensive RTS gameplay of the original [i]Men of War[/i] into multiplayer. In this game you also micromanage every single unit and have to deal with realistic logistical problems on a tactical level. However, instead of a dumb AI, you are against a human opponent who must do the same. No other multiplayer RTS has infantry and vehicle combat like this. 

Just like in the original game you control every individual soldier's equipment and actions. With good micro you can use a single soldier to wipe out whole squads or even multiple destroy tanks. Surprise attacks are insanely deadly as soldiers have realistic HP and most tanks can be destroyed with a single anti-tank grenade.

You also control every vehicle and must deal with their historical limitations. Vehicle crews must be protected, fuel supplies must be maintained, and each part of the tank must be repaired when damaged. The game's point system and large maps encourage the use of light vehicles and medium vehicles instead of just a stream of heavy tanks. No other game highlights the  historical strengths of these lighter vehicles like this game. However, the game's realism makes infantry with the right positioning and equipment a hard counter to vehicles. 

The game is not entirely historically accurate. Vehicles that never went past being blueprints exist in the game and the game does not use unit cost or modifiers to represent the historical productivity or quality of the troops of the respective countries. The game bends reality to create a balanced experience. This can be fixed easily, because the game supports mods and has many of them. 

The first [i]Men of War: Assault Squad[/i] no longer supports multiplayer and does not have a good single player experience. The single player does not have a story and most missions are the same 5 missions but reskinned for each of the factions. You should not buy the first version of the game because this game is basically the same game, but with functional multiplayer.

I bought this because it looked like the next best thing to a World War II game (and all the FPS world war II games are just completely hardcore or optimized to steal peoples money as of right now). I got this because it looked like it would really capture the essence of world war II, and in a way it does, but unlike the shooters, this game just requires way too much strategy (ironic, because this IS a strategy game). Yes that's the point of the game, but you really have to have a serious in-depth knowledge of world war II to accomplish your tasks, beyond just knowing that the Soviets liked to suicide rush en masse, the Japanese LITERALLY suicide rushed, and the Germans just had superior tech. You need to know how to counter specific armaments in the battlefield in real-time. I went on the Workshop for this and got cheats to allow me to hopefully just enjoy the game by rushing in large amounts of troops at once, however, in some situations, the AI will counter you perfectly. This is good for someone who is hardcore, but for me, I didn't want a super hardcore experience and to instead just blast some people as whatever faction using the cool troops and tanks and stuff. Instead, I was spamming so many units into the field, with the AI also spamming so many units, that all the dead tanks and troops on the field would tank my frames per second (FPS). I tried to enjoy the game, yes I got a lot of hours, but in the end, I won't be revisiting this, and don't really recommend it to anyone.

This game, its fanbase, and the developers are pure, crystallized AIDs.  The only reason people still play this, is nobody has a better alternative and thus the stagnation continues.  I recommend this to nobody unless you have a fundamental disregard for your free time, and any vestige of a social life.

As it is, I'll continue to play this because The hate for myself outweighs my hate for this game, but I urge you to avoid this unless, as I do you find fault with modern games, and want to repeatedly bang your head against this buggy, 32 bit dinosaur of a Russian monstrosity.  

In short, go play literally anything else, and you'll probably thank yourself later.

Thankfully, if I remember correctly some doofus actually bought me this game all those years back, so the only money I've actually spent on it was buying the DLC that readded goddamn _bots_ into the game.  

Run away, far, far away and you'll live a more satisfying life.  Cheers, I hope you fall off a cliff.

Muy buen juego, la franquicia en general es algo que por haya en 2008 cuando probe me encanto y me hizo volver años mas tarde a jugarlo, este juego al igual que su predecesor siguen una formula que a mi parecer sirve muy bien para mantener a lo largo de los años vivo a la comunidad, la campaña no es nada del otro mundo, dependiendo de como lo veas es repetitivo, hay una serie de misiones que varian segun el tipo de objetivos y lo unico que cambia es la nacion y algunos detalles que encontras por ahi...Pero el multiplayer esta muy bien, es disfrutable por horas en vanilla y metiendome con mods hay una gran variedad, hay 3 mods que son clave desde que salio en 2014, el galaxy at war, el valour y el Robzrealism, estos 3 permiten por un lado la creacion infinita de mapas y contenidos, en youtube se refleja mucho esto, y por otro lado el multiplayer se vuelve muy grande y da lugar a miles mas de posibilidades, orque llega un punto que el vanilla o juego base llega a estancarse, si jugaste las anteriores entregas, sentis que necesita una historia parecida a Red Tide o misiones mas a lo que se asemejaban en el primer men of war. Los graficos realmente no avanzan tanto si los comparas a 2008, aunque no es su punto fuerte, la jugabilidad mejora cada entrega, tenes muchos accesos directos que hacen que fluya muy bien cuando guias tropas, pero creo que opinando por varios, una historia haria que el apartado offline se luzca mucho mas, no hablo de nada muy elaborado, pero si que nos incite a queres jugar primero el modo historia completo y no saltar directamente al multijugador. Mi nota: 8/10

This game is a peculiar sense of fun.
Most games you boot up and expect to be assured any amount of fun or satisfaction. This game however, this game is different. No, you don't boot this game up and expect fun, you boot this game up and gamble on fun but not only that, because your sanity is also part of that deal, oh yes, you're always doubling down on this game. Here is a rough transcript of a game going downhill:
"Alright boys, I'm gonna side armor his SU-100 with my Veteran Tiger, get a sniper to spot infy for me..."
"...my Veteran Tiger's tracked but I got the SU-100, put some infy on me while I repair..."
"...hey... do you guys hear that?"
"OH MOTHER OF PEARL THEY HAVE A SUPER PERSHING DITCH THE TIGER, DITCH THE TIGER!"
And then subsequent to your foe's purchase of an outstanding counter-buy and your teammates' reliance on your expensive buy, your economy is crippled for the rest of the game and you resort to infantry buys that stand no match to your opponent's stronger economy and supply of mechanized ordnance.
When these things happen, you feel absolutely hopeless, to lose important units and realize what position you've put yourself in provides a near harrowing feeling.
But on the other hand, when this game goes well, it goes damn well. When you side armor that Super Pershing that was giving you such a hard time with your Panzer 4H, and you're the one to send your opponent's economy into hell letting you walk away the victor... believe me, there is no better feeling. You can be down 0-99 and turn a game around, there is always room for a comeback and plenty of it. And while you may feel clueless when you start playing, there is noticeable improvement day by day if not hour by hour when playing this game. You learn to buy and move troops around fast and safely, deploy sandbags, direct control infantry and vehicles, swap weapons, know when and why you use what kinds of ammunition and utility, navigate unit inventories, cook grenades, pickup items, etc. It sounds tough but is picked up easily and improved upon quickly.

So back to what I was saying about this game being a peculiar sense of fun. When this game goes bad, and you lose 3 matches in the same night and you feel like you're the damn worst at the game of all of the people who have ever purchased it, no game is worse than this one. But when this game goes good, and you win all 3 matches you played that night, not only that but you absolutely WIPED THE FLOOR with the fellows you played against... oh lord, it doesn't get better. No amount of illicit substances nor illegal services can ever liken itself to the level of serotonin released when you have a good time in this game. It should be a talking point in quantum mechanics for it is both the best and worst game in my entire steam library.

So, in conclusion, if you have the money and this game is on a fair sale, I recommend buying the War Chest edition, but don't stress the wallet if need not be. The replays DLC helps greatly if you ever want to work on improving your gameplay or play-style or in my case, admire the moment I sent a Super Pershing to kingdom come out of pride.

Extremely irritating mechanics and absolutely bizarre default hotkeys, map control, etc. I hate it when games do this.

The absolute worst part of this game is that there is LITERALLY NO OPTION TO ATTACK MOVE your support weapons. Want your mortars to fire at enemies at their maximum range, then keep up supporting their team instead of just sitting there...? Too bad. You literally CAN NOT. Period.

You will instead have to manually set up, unset, move, and then manually attack ground or the enemy unit. Then repeat for all your other support weapons on all the enemies you want to attack. Oh yeah and there's no freaking control groups, AND you can't move units on the absolutely useless minimap. Seriously? It's like playing a 90s RTS title waving my mouse around to control units manually. Frustrating and annoying to play. I was very disappointed and I don't want that frustration of not having control over my own units. 

The minimap is extremely bizarre. There's no reason to make the right click the option to see the part on the map. That should be for ... MOVING YOUR UNITS?..... Duh...?

Bizarre mechanics and obvious oversights by developers in basic unit control makes this game unplayable and the battles just look stupid and zany without constant micro attention. Like some of your guys suddenly forget there's a battle going on because they don't move a few inches to help their dying bunkmates.

Maybe when Men of War 4 comes out they'll figure out how control groups and attack move is supposed to work in other RTS titles. No unit control.

In fact, it's extremely ironic how UNREALISTIC certain parts of this game are. Downright wonky seeing your mortar team just sit there and let his bunkmates he just had breakfast with just die in front of him.... because he CANT move like 3 feet in front of him to support his guys. You can't order him to do that. You have to unpack manually and do it yourself.

Now if that happened in real life he would get court martialed or something. It's hard to feel the immersion of the game when your soldiers are fucking dumb as hell. Dumb as rocks, because the developers failed to put in a few standard control mechanics and details expected of every RTS title. Like being able to create control groups for your units, and moving units on the minimap.

When your troops run up to the enemy to gun them down, they must come to a COMPLETE STOP like there's a cop waiting to write them a ticket somewhere, and then let their friends die before they decide to take cover somewhere you didn't specify, then shoot. Because their arms are paralyzed while walking or running with full auto weapons, which are specifically designed to be used that way. Your MG team will suicide walk to the enemy if you attack move them, not set up and attack.

I mean... this game can really beat COH2. I wish. But it's more zany than realistic combat if you ask me in its current state. It doesn't do enough respect to the men who actually served. Idiot bot troops who just stand there while their buddies die, or suicide walk unless you specifically tell them where to set up. At least they take cover which is realistic like CoH2. But there's not enough realistic detail or control over your units. You are commanding human beings who can get scared, need ammo, weather protection, food, etc, not bot troops. The closer these guys come to achieving that level of realism the better. I'm just so disappointed in how badly this game plays.

CoH2 is better until this is fixed in their next game, but honestly I'm waiting for something to finally dethrone them. Maybe MoW3 can?????? Hopefully. Please fix.

You require the Origins DLC in order to have a decent campaign because the devs were honestly lazy as hell and didn't bother making an interesting one; The vanilla AS2 campaigns are rubbish and excessively repetitive and tedious.

The core game mechanics are pretty great, with a strong emphasis on cover for infantry that lets you micromanage to your hearts content. The direct control is also good for more precise movement... if a little janky. The variety between factions is OK with special units but mostly boils down to pretty much identical standard units with different voice lines and weapon skins (with a few exceptions here and there) the game looks and sounds fine too, but the biggest weakness is in the campaigns. there are several campaigns to choose from including axis and allied factions but all missions are repetitive "capture 10 identically placed zones in some maps that often feel uninspired" or "defend 3 identically placed outer defenses and one central defense" that's all the mission variety with the exact same objectives in each level for each faction, with changes in maps. e.g. the British second mission is the capture 10 objectives in North Africa, the Americans do the same mission on a European map, the Japanese in a jungle and the soviets in a city. There are also DLC missions where you can use a stealthy infiltration or be in direct control of a tank. Both are dreadful. The tank is clunky and hard to control and the stealth is so poorly done, the devs give you an option to skip it all together.(in fairness the section of the mission after the stealth has slightly better variety) I would not recommend this game if it weren't for the excellent modding community. They have made the game great fun with new mechanics, missions and a proper D-Day mission.(thanks RobZ) Overall the good gameplay mechanics and mods get this game a recommendation, just don't bother yourself with the vanilla missions.

I cannot in good conscience reccomend this game for anything other than using the editor & modding scene to create interesting scenarios. 

The game feels extremely unpolished, even more than six years after initial release. There is very little feed back on your actions, including feedback on why you often can't fire a weapon (More on that later)

The game is initially fun and fascinating, especially if you pick up mods for the game, or are particularly interested in WW2 simulators or wargames.


Pros:
-Lovely art direction and well done models.
-Somewhat interesting singleplayer missions, until you realize that several are copypasted between campaigns.
-Modding scene has some decent stuff such as 40k, Vietnam, and various overhaul and content mods.
-Pretty cheap when it's on sale. The only time I would reccomend buying it.
-Decent editor for creating and filming AI scenarios. There's some pretty cool video content on youtube.


Cons: (long ones explained in full at the bottom)
-Extremely unintuitive UI.
-No real tutorial, so everything must be learned yourself, via guides, or via a friend.
-Annoying inventory management system.
-AI is sold to you as a DLC, and it's a DLC that doesn't even work properly. 
-Poor damage models.


The UI has far too many buttons spread out across the keyboard, often needing you to press multiple buttons to perform a single action such as using anything in the inventory. Information is spread out across your HUD, and a lot of it isn't properly explained, even with tooltips. The inventory management system is very nice and interesting for singleplayer, but serves next to no purpose in multiplayer, other than refilling ammunition. None of your infantry will survive long enough to scavenge off of bodies, and ammo refills are automated when you have ammo trucks.

Dozens of units and abilities have missing names or tooltips, only showing the filepath of unit's information/name in the game's rootfolder. Am I supposed to go treasure hunting for these?!

AI is sold to you as a barely functioning DLC. The game won't tell you what content someone is missing in the lobby ("Resource desync detected"), and many maps & co-op missions are locked behind DLC. Aside from being a DLC, the AI doesn't even work properly. The nature of the resource system means that the AI will just bumrush you with any units it spawns, and eventually just run out of units and start spawning them very infrequently. Oh and the AI only has one objective: Attack the flags. It'll never ever flank or do anything remotely interesting. Won't even patrol between flags. This has been confirmed by modders & people poking into the code.

Damage modelling is often horrific. Some units have absolute pinpoint accuracy and damage in comparison to units of the same 'slot' on other factions. Sometimes infantry will just lazer eachother from halfway across the map, and sometimes they'll stand there and be unable to hit, or even shoot, at someone sitting 3 feet away from them taking potshots. Both the passive AI for units, and direct orders, often lead to ridiculous situations like the AI running through a building only to throw an Anti-Tank grenade right into their squadmates.

Tank combat is horrific. The devs 'balanced' a lot of the vehicles by altering their historical armour values and gun ranges & penetration rates to accentuate their purposes. Weapon range is directly tied to calibre and ammo used (Bigger gun longer ranged, APCR rounds drastically reduce range); However it is done so in such a way that you'll have US Tank Destroyers that outrange almost every other vehicle, and are practically unkillable without being snuck up on by infantry.

Direct Control is an interesting, but poorly implemented, feature. It allows you to 'take control' of any unit in the game, and manually aim where they fire. This is pretty much the only way to use most artillery units, as they'll refuse to fire-on-location, and will only free-fire at units inside of an arbitrary range that is well below their actual range. Unfortunately the Direct Control  UI provides absolutely no feedback on why you won't be able to fire a weapon. Yellow means reduced effectiveness, red means out of range, and green means well within range. But outside of that, you'll be faced with dozens of unexplained reasons why you cannot actually fire your weapon, and the top-down perspective makes it doubly difficult to determine why. On the flipside, a master of Direct Control will absolutely ruin any other player in the game with a ridiculously high skill ceiling.

Vehicle damage is often silly and seemingly RNG, except we've been told that these run on statistics and not RNG. Which means some of these are at the very least, deliberate choices.

Here's some examples:

-M12 GMC's which take 7 rear point blank Panzerfausts, 3 german AT grenades, and a belt of ammo from an Ostwind to permanently destroy.
-Jagdtigers which get completely destroyed in one max-range shot from a Bazooka
-PzIII's who get fired on by SU-85's for five minutes straight with no damage inflicted, bouncing every non-angled frontal shot.
-PzIV's who bounce M36 Slugger 90mm rounds multiple times in a row with no angling.
-Rounds inexplicably overpenetrating or bouncing off of a target and causing absolutely no damage to a vehicle or it's occupants, despite the UI telling you that you have a clear and effective shot.

There's so many different things you can do after you beat the basegame. I highly recommend downloading mods from the Steam Workshop, opens up many different possibilities for the game. I highly recommend playing.

Babies play Company of Heroes 1/2. Then the babies grow up to be boys, and then the boys play Men of War Assault Squad 2 and find the true meaning of PTSD as you sent young stupid conscripts to their deaths for a control point that has long lost meaning and for purposes they cannot grasp. War is hell.

Now that the spiritual successor Gates of Hell has sadly entered development hell this is the only ww2 real time tactics game (we don't talk about Arena) that still holds up. It's complicated as hell, and theres mods that make it even more complicated as hell. It has a good mix of micro and macro and every unit has their own inventory and you can even control each unit individually or as any sized clump you could want. This is one of those games that's easy to get into but hard as hell to master. 

Just be aware this is more of a multiplayer game, there are singleplayer options but they leave more to be desired. 

As with any game that might pique your interest get it on sale if you can, it usually goes dirt cheap during sales, best bang for your buck if you can fetch it under 10$.

Time for a serious review. My previous review of this game was just the words "good enough" and after 1,500 hours with this thing, I think I can give an ok opinion.

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a mixed package. There are so many blessings and problems its hard to find a place to start.

First of all, its important to clear up the fact that I don't play multiplayer much, or at all. This is due in part to one of the major problems with all Digitalmindsoft games, and that is Netcode. The networking for multiplayer is, in simple terms, shite. My laptop isn't exactly butter smooth when it comes to playing, so part of the blame can be put on me, but just know that to play multiplayer with this game is to accept the fact that your performance (hardware wise) will be downgraded to the level of the player with the worst setup, and that you will experience constant crashes due to memory allocation or etc.

A blessing that this game has is probably the best modding community I've seen for games. You can't overhaul the game and make new mechanics (some people have but they're relatively unpolished) but you can modify the entities within the game (vehicles, soldiers, weapons) which really are the things that matter. From mods like RobZ realism (good for immersion), #Valour (the best way to reach the vanilla experience) or my personal favourite, the Cold War mod, you can do a lot with mods and the maps some people have made.

Possibly the biggest problem with this game is the memory issues, and the fact that it was built for 32 bit OSs, and while it still runs on 64 bit OSs, you'll have a LOT of memory allocation crashes, barring you from playing many missions or multiplayer matches.

The game is also lacking in polish. Animations are janky, sound effects are old, graphical effects are kind of low res, and most of all, the textures for a lot of things are odd to say the least. There is a huge inconsistency between vehicles in the game, with the new Ostfront Veteranen faction having very high quality models, and the Japanese faction having vehicles that are borderline pixel art.

The culture around the game is built from youtubers with clickbait thumbnails, and apparently some russians are hacking now.

Do I recommend you get this game? Hell yes, I got 1,500 hours out of it for what its worth.
Is it 100% guaranteed you'll enjoy it? No, its probably more guaranteed you won't.
I get my kick of dopamine from creating things in the editor. At it's core, I feel like the game is just the GEM editor with a semi polished base over the top. The GEM editor is simply put- think of toy army men when you were a kid. You'd set them up, enact battles between them, you can do that with the GEM editor and even make them kind of autonomous. Watch them fight, control one side, that's the magic of this game.

So should you buy it? Yeah, give it a try. I recommend you do.If you don't enjoy it, I don't blame you. Its not everyone's thing. But by god if this isn't my favourite game of all time.

Assault Squad 2 is a great and very complex RTS game, that is very unlike all the other RTSes that I played outside the Men of War series, especially if you play on higher difficulties. The learning curve is rather steep and as you start to learn the game there will be frustrating moments. But as you learn how to play you will be rewarded with a great feeling of accomplishment, when you see how you grew with the challenge and win your first skirmish on "heroic" (hardest) difficulty. When I started out I failed many missions on "normal" and thought "how is this even possible to win on 'hard' ?" Well it is - with knowledge and skill. I know few games in this genre that give you this much power to change the outcome of a battle with pure skill. You can take direct control of every soldier and vehicle and for example aim that one important grenade throw just the way you want it or position a tank precisely behind the ruins of a house, with just a window to shoot through etc.. Replayability is great, buildings can be destroyed, which makes for a very dynamic battlefield and you can hardcore micromanage every single soldier down to picking up equipment from fallen enemies. 
It has its flaws and will drive you mad at times, but still I highly recommend it to anyone looking for skill based RTS with a lot of micromanagement, complex mechanics and all around rather grim and realistic feel to it. Also check out "Call to Arms" once it is released. I'm having high hopes for it, although I haven't played it yet.


Update on 2020-06-20: 
Just thought I should add that over 5 years later this is still hands down the best WW2 RTS and my favorite RTS in general. It's soon gonna move up to being my second most played game on steam and I know I'm still gonna have a lot of fun with it in years to come. If you don't own this already and you have ever liked an RTS game, you should definitely check this one out!

It's a very good RTS and arguably the best amongst WW2 themed ones. If you like complexity and attention to detail you'll not be dissapointed. In ths game every unit, even every foot soldier has a fricking inventory! and this becomes relevant when they need to carry supplies. Infantry need ammo, medical supplies and other stuff while vehicles also spend fuel so you need to think in the supply chain which is something I haven't seen any other game address before. models and animations are also well made and while ammo, for infantry at least, is not that historically accurate (submachine gun ammo, rifle ammo, etc. instead of .45 mm, 9mm etc) there's a mod that adds accurate ammo (only bad thing is it doesn't work with campaign because all the generic ammo the units appear with will not work). The vanilla game also comes with a silly censoring on a flag (you can guess which) but is easily fixed with a mod. 

Totally recomended.

One of the best RTS games out there and one that focuses a bit more on micromanagement of your units. It has aspects that make it more of a simulation, like loading ammunition into trucks and units, setting up machine guns and other weapons strategically and generally fighting for street blocks or hills. It's a very tactical experience. Taking it slow, generally means a better chance of survival. And missions tend to take their fair bit of time. But it's definitely worth it. Also, still holds up great visually!! Worth a try if you're into WW2 strategy games.

[h1][b]Direct Control is the best[/b][/h1]
[i]Men of War Assault Squad 2 is one of my favourite RTS game, if not my most favourite. After all these years MoW AS2 is still good and playable game, but it has some negative things. I own Deluxe Edition.[/i]

The game offers single-player missions and multiplayer. Missions are good, I think. You will enjoy few defence missions, skirmish and stealth too. Skirmish is about capturing zones on a map. The new captured zone will unlock new units and give you more points to call reinforcements. One skirmish can take more than an hour. Its dependence on difficulty settings. You can control units of Russia, USA, Britain, Germany and Japan. The game engine is old and has only 32 bits support but the game run relatively good.

Multiplayer offers serval modes. Assault Zones, you must capture more zones than an enemy. More zones you have, the more points you will get. Combat, destroy more units than an enemy. Frontline contains two rounds. In the first round, one team is defending positions and others try to break the frontline. In the second round, sides will switch. Who defends in the first round will be attacker in the second round. The game offer coop too, but there is a strange reinforcement calling system. If you have more units than your coop partner and you call a new unit, then the game will give this unit to your partner but he can give this unit back to you. This balance is for to everyone have the same number of units but sometimes it's annoying, especially if you call a tank and the game decides to give that tank to another player. Performance of multiplayer is sometimes bad. If one player in the lobby has potato PC, you will see lags and even pause during gameplay. This the worst thing in this game, but nothing horrible.

Now, the best thing in MoW AS2. It's Direct Control. It makes the game special. You can control the whole squad of soldiers or you can control one man by using WASD keys and mouse, just like in 3rd person shooter. Of course, you can use DC in vehicles and tanks too. You can aim better and destroy tank faster than automatical aim by AI when you order your unit to eliminate an enemy. Vehicles have many parts which can be destroyed or damaged. For example, you can destroy the main gun on a tank, destroy engine or damage turret to prevent it rotating. Have always a few soldiers around your tank because an enemy can use the advantage of the lonely tank and destroy it with one soldier by an anti-tank grenade. Very frustrating sometimes, so be careful.

Another nice feature which makes this game unique and great is the editor. If you bored of single-player or multiplayer you can enjoy a lot of fun in GEM editor. You can make own maps like in other editors of games, but one thing is unique here. You can play with all units like a child on sandbox with toys. Load up a multiplayer map, spawn some units and start a battle. You can look at units how they fight each other or you can control them. This can be incredibly funny.

Do you like modern vehicles? Do you like realism? Do you like the USA Civil War? Do you like Star Wars? You can find everything in the workshop or Mod DB. My favourite mod is [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=455424236&searchtext=valour]Valour. [/url] It adds new factions like Finland, France, Poland and many more. It changes textures, models, sounds, effects, damage system, etc. Valour adds new features and makes the game more realistic. Modders keep alive this nice RTS game. The modding community is big and active.

[b]It's 6 years since the game was released but MoW AS2 is still good and playable. You can still enjoy the game without mods. I prefer to play with [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=455424236&searchtext=valour]Valour[/url] mod. If you want to buy MoW AS2 take Airborne DLC too. You will get bots for multiplayer Assault Zones mode. Do I recommend Men of War Assault Squad 2 to you? Yes, but wait for a sale. You will like this game if you like RTS games and you want something special. Direct Control is the best thing. I never see this in other RTS games except for Men of War series and Call to Arms.[/b]

Micromanaging and attention to details (penetration chances, damage zones on vehicles, different types of shells, individual inventory on every soldier, ability to pick up enemy guns etc.) are on a level not found in any other RTS, you can even choose to control any unit on your own. However, micromanaging and direct control are not optional. Failing to understand and master these mechanics will end in failure and frustration on harder levels. In fact, even if you manage to master these mechanics they are still frustrating and having your soldier taking a scenic route through enemy fortification to jump over a fence in front of him is a daily occurrence on the battlefield. Controls are clunky and AI knows no cool tricks to help you with managing. I imagine those aspects of gameplay weren't touched since very first games in the series. If you can stay sane while learning how to not get your infantry wiped and having your armor one-shotted you are in for a challenging world war 2 RTS that offers a different approach with more "realistic" feeling to it.

And you can make make a war hero from a random infantryman by stealing an MG. You can have an entire squad carrying heavy machine guns mowing down everything in their path as well. That is, if you manage to find time to manually get every single one of them to pick up some of the machine guns scattered around while there are waves of infantry pushing on your positions and enemy tanks advancing.

It's a great WW2 RTS. It gets a lot of comparisons to Company of Heroes 2 and rightfully so. They're both very similar but Men of war definitely has more realistic aspects and its more in depth. You can control individual soldiers, inspect vehicles and retrieve different items from them, dig foxholes, lay down sandbags and tanks can have individual parts that can be destroyed like the tracks or the turret. Unlike Company of Heroes this game has [b] over 250 vehicles[/b] not including DLC's or mods. These vehicles range from Basic artillery to large howitzers that fire massive shells on your enemy to many many tanks. If you want to experience all the vehicles you should go into the editor where everything is available. You can have soldiers fight or set up your own missions.  I haven't even touched the online multiplayer and have just played the single player and messed around in the editor. The price is a bit steep though. There are a lot of mods such as a WW1 mod and even a [b]Star Wars[/b] mod that completely overhauls the game. There are many maps, vehicles, and other stuff on the steam workshop. Although the price is a bit steep. I would personally wait for a sale which happens quite often. Overall pretty good game which introduced me to the RTS genre.

This is the game we have been waiting for!  Finally we are able to create units with equipment of a modern Army.  I am an Army Officer and have been playing strategy games with another Army  friend since were teenagers playing on hex maps all the way to professional defense contractor simulations.  This game can be played in a quasi age of empires kind of way, but more interestingly for real military strategists, this game has the potential to actually conduct military missions at the platoon level according to actual Army field manuals (FM).  I am specifically referring to the World War 3 mod.  The developers are updating almost everyday and the mod keeps getting better.  We still need more CPs to fully equip units according to actual Modified Tables of Organization and Equipment (MTOE) and aircraft for Air Assault and Medevac, then you will be able to lead an actual units.  My friend and I wait in an Assembly Area (AA) until we build a complete unit, then begin to send out patrols and operate at a certain H-Hour like actual units.  Coordination of an H-Hour allows for a pre-planned missions with routes, rally points and objectives like leading an actual unit.  For those looking for a simulation that allows you to plan as an actual Army leader, this game provides the framework.

I'll preface this by saying this game is fun when it "works" (balanced teams, good performance, etc). But with randoms it only works about once every 10 games or if you have friends to play with.

For singleplayer this game is fine but I'm not sure why you would buy it for singleplayer. 

The core of this "game" is the PvP multiplayer, but the multiplayer is so broken performance wise that it's an insult to other game developers to call the multiplayer a game. Unless you can ensure everyone in your lobby has ~50 ms ping then the game will run like a slideshow and you will be able to count the number of seconds of lag between you sending out orders and your units reacting. It's somewhat more bearable if you have friends to play PvP or modded missions with because chances are your ping will then be reasonable, but if not then I don't recommend you buy this game. 

The actual game aside, the community is also a$$ when it comes to multiplayer. Not only is the community dying, but it's of very low quality too. Randoms will leave if you're beating them (sometimes I can't even blame them if it's because of lag or unbalanced teams, because then it's just 100% not fun to play), and it takes ages to find an actual game. I have never seen a host make an effort to balance teams, and it seems I'm the only one who tries to do this when I host. Again, if you have friends to play with these drawbacks are mitigated somewhat. 

It's really a shame because in theory the concept is really good. The game just runs on decade old technology with shitty netcode and for some reason still with a 32-bit executable because apparently this game was developed in 2005. The developers don't care, the last thing they did over a year ago was release an unbalanced faction for DLC.

It is most definitely one of the best RTS games around. But it is not without its flaws. I found it difficult to get through a full campaign for any faction as I simply got bored with the predictable enemy AI, over-complicated micromanagement of units and frustration of constantly having to micromanage my units in a way that was too complicated. 

See how I said the same thing, twice, in a long-winded fashion? That's what it feels like to have to select a squad, choose an individual squad member, have them look in a disabled vehicle, open their inventory, move the jerry can over, select the jerry can, walk them to the friendly tank out of gas and fill it up to 3%, return to the disabled vehicle and fill the jerry can, return to the friendly tank to get it up to 6%, and so on... Meanwhile, the enemy sniper has killed the other half of that poor guys squad and I can hear the distinct sound of a Panzer coming from my left flank which I have't had time to reinforce because I was getting gas for my Sherman.

Really fun mechanics for squad-level gameplay, far too much for anything platoon sized and above.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is an interesting game. It's an amazing game to play with friends and I've loved every moment with my friends playing this, all the laughs, anger over BS, and sh*talking. But after the games you play and think about the game itself...... Yeah it's not the best nor optimized game around, and there are also some marketing practices in this game that really makes me mad. 

 FIRST of all, you have to buy a freaking DLC to fight A.I. in skirmish! This game is not for you if you don't have friends or enjoy competitive matches every now and then. The campaign isn't very good and the mission concept are the same for each faction, neat to go though first time though. Because you have to buy a DLC for A.I. you have to learn the hard way and join multiplayer games so you will either lose hardcore without learning too much or get kicked for being new to the game but that's not a big things anymore. This game can get really competitive so hosts wanted better players. You won't be helpless though, I wasn't but I'm just saying what could happen for some people. 
 And second is the game isn't optimized well and the game even tells everyone to restart their games often to prevent crashes especially if you use any mods but they were too busy making the disaster which was the Cold War version of this game. 

 Now if you have the A.I. or don't care about the issues I put above then this game is the right game for you.
The game has so much going on in multiplayer and I love it so much and...... If you use mods like ROBZ Realism mod.... You just made yourself a better man. Holy crap the mods in this game are absolutely fantastic and they all work in multiplayer to have fun with friends or just in online sessions you can host. A big majority of online games usually use the ROBZ Realism mob because it essentially adds onto the game and adds so much more including game elements, the game is a lot better with it. I highly advise getting this mod in the steam workshop but a little warning that the A.I. won't work in mods but that shouldn't matter. The modding community is insane in this game, you could be fighting in a modified WW2 to insane battles between STAR WARS FIGHTING WARHAMMER FACTIONS with your friends! You can probably tell that I've talked about playing with friends, I've personally enjoyed this game far more than anything just goofing around with my friends than anything else. Going into a random online session is always fun as well.

When I first bought this game, I thought it would be just another generic World War 2 RTS, akin to Command and Conquer. When I actually played it, I was blown away. The graphics are stunning, the combat is realistic and much, much more detailed than I had expected, and it actually immerses you. I felt bad for every soldier or vehicle that died or was destroyed in the multiplayer or singleplayer. It can just be written off as a graphical and mechanical upgrade of AS1, but it's fun as all hell. Mods are abundant and a lot of them have blood, sweat and tears poured into them. It's amazing to see what people put out for this game. The only problem i have with it is the amount of crashes. any mods that conflicted would crash, and I'd have to individually delete them from my subscription list to single out the one that caused the crash. That annoyed me, but that's about it. Great game, I'd suggest it to anyone that likes a detailed RTS.

Assault Squad 2 is a fantastic addition to the Men of War series and a worthy sequel to Assault Squad 1.  It takes the amazing models and 3D rts singleplayer gameplay of the mainline singleplayer series and turns it into  multiplayer paradise. You still get single player missions in the form of a skirmish campaign, plus the dlc expansions that add more single player missions.

The models look realistic with well made textures and attention to detail to reflect their real world counterparts.  There are tons of options and customization settings to set up singleplayer, online, or local matches for singleplayer or multiplayer.  The mod community is also very active and give you even further options in the form of updates, maps, missions, units, and more.  

Very much looking forward to more updates, expansions, dlc, or even an Assault Squad 3.  Look into Call to Arms for a modern warfare alternative.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/8714972/] Please follow [b]TotalWar:Arena[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h1]Men of War: Assault Squad 2 Review[/h1]
Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a Real-Time Strategy (RTS) and Tactics game set in the second world war. It is developed by Digitalmindsoft and published by 1C Entertainment. The game fully released in March 2014 exclusively for Windows on Steam after leaving a small period of early access. It is the sequel of Men of War: Assault Squad with a substantial engine upgrade and a new revamped multiplayer system.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
If you are new to Men of War, it is not like any other generic RTS games; it's more of a Game of combat rather than resource management. It incorporates everything from its predecessor, so AS2  has a truckload of content and missions. You take control over one of the five distinct armies with their unique vehicles, personal weapons, and camouflage. Each mission has the same mix of objectives; what differs is the faction you play and the map. Some of them include infiltration, defense, skirmish, and Tank skirmish. Your primary goal is always to suppress your enemy, call more troops, and finish the objective or eradicate the enemy in any manner possible.
The game features a singleplayer skirmish mode that can be played alone or with friends. But the game lacks an AI, and bots require a separate paid DLC; hence the game is best enjoyed in multiplayer. The multiplayer features 1v1 to 8v8 modes, each designed for strategic battles and different experiences.
What differs in AS2 that there is a self-learning curve rather than the game just flinging tips at you, which leaves you open for experimenting with every feature in the game. There is ample micromanagement that even steeps down to individual soldiers. Every single unit has its separate inventory, which can be sorted & scavenged. If your troop runs out of ammo, it displays a red ammo clip over its head. Similarly, you'll have to manage ammo, bandages and grenades, and trenching equipment of every soldier on the battlefield. But this micromanagement can be avoided by the timely use of supply crate that automatically replenishes the ammunition of soldiers, but the game doesn't tell you that straight up and forces you to learn it the hard way. Not only that but also, learning to resupply squads with a single click, how to rearrange and organize shattered units after an attack, and how to gain ground without exposing troops to enemy armor; such strategies and tactics will be useful in multiplayer because fire and movement make up the basis of most of these tactics.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Realism and detailing in AS2 makes the game very engaging. Vehicles don't have hitboxes; instead, their essential parts break down, unlike having a general health bar. Tanks can get stuck, run out of fuel, become immobile, or get wrecked by AT guns. Every unit can counter and be countered as is expected in real life. E.g., Anti-tank guns are excellent against tanks, posing a threat to even the tougher ones and knocking them out of action. Machine guns are useful to rip apart enormous waves of infantry but will do nothing against armor. Mortars do severe damage at enemy positions but are entirely unpredictable & inaccurate. Overall you'll have to command each of your men to prone, crouch, stand ground, fire, and control their movement and position as this isn't a game where you can just place troops and just forget about them. 
Apart from that, AS2 also features a 'direct control' mechanism by which you can trigger control over any troop or tank as if it were a third-person shooter. You'll automatically lock over the shoulder of the unit and can control its rifle/gun, move around and shoot.

[h1]Graphics[/h1] 
The graphics haven't changed majorly in AS2. But they shouldn't be the primary concern either as you'll be watching the game from a height. The maps live up to the thematic element of WW2 and are vividly designed to be fully destructible. It is almost satisfying to watch buildings crumble after getting hit by a shell, seeing tanks break down, etc.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
The game is very strategic and skill-based. The singleplayer is lackluster, but multiplayer makes up for it. The game supports modding, and you can have endless hours of fun with that, its dedicated steam workshop, designing your custom missions and mods. Note there aren't any updates of late, and some bugs still exist along with server sync issues in multiplayer. But still, it has a great community until the date and definitely worth the buy even in 2020.

Rate: 8/10

Of all the WWII RTS games out there, this one has to be in my top five most satisfying.  A wide range of units, no shortage of awesome visuals and strategies, and one of the only RTS games that let you take direct control of a unit.... or redistribute ammo and weapons between units.  There's a layer of complexity here that's not mandatory to fully explore, but it gives the game that extra omf other WWII titles just don't have.  A classic reworked into a modern masterpiece for its time, and it still keeps me coming back today.  1C Entertainment, you done did good.

Basic MDA Analysis:
Aesthetics: Challenge, Abnegation, Fantasy.  This is one title that will have you coming back again and again, especially thanks to mods and base game replayability.  There's a layer of challenge involved in taking on players and higher tier AI opponents.  Live the fantasy of being a commander in World War Two, or take to the front by taking direct control of soldiers, armored cars, artillery pieces, and tanks.
Dynamics: With complex array of units, weapons, and tactical options, players are challenged to come up with unique, abstract ways to overcome unique developments against an AI that's not gonna play nice at higher difficulty levels.
Mechanics: Summarized by efficient RTS control scheme with a twist.  Weapons, ammo, and equipment can be picked up from the battlefield or interchanged between soldiers through accessible unit and vehicle inventories.  Objective is field control, player who takes all command posts wins.  (Primary game mode is a Tug of War).

Let's face it, this little analysis of mine doesn't do the game justice from a player's perspective.  Just try it out for yourself.  For you devs out there, you might get what I did here.

Men of Wars: Assault Squad 2. An excellent tactical RTS game that is WW2 themed. This game, compared to other WW2 themed RTS is a much more tactical, and less arcade type of game. 

Buying the normal game, you will be... a bit disappointed... There is no private verse AI option that isn't the preset missions (Which are mostly waiting missions), and the only way to play with the normal skirmish modes is to play online (Unless you are lucky enough to have friends that own this game). Worse yet, the AI verse function is locked away by a $10 DLC...


... well, geezes, so, why do I still recommend it?... Well, it's because it's an excellent game otherwise.
Compared to it's younger brother, Call to Arms, the base game comes with 5 factions, fully worked on. This means mutliplayer is basically fair playing grounds for everyone. This is before we include mods.

Of course I understand the $30 price tag is daunting... especially with how the game is sold, with it's somewhat cash-grab DLC (I mean, one DLC is actually a $7 achievement), though that should not stop you from enjoying the game. Even the missions alone can give you 100+ hours of gameplay if you play the game completely base.
... just, if you can't afford the game, get it during a holiday sale...

I'm a big fan of the RTS genre and I don't know why I waited so long to play this game. It's like company of heros but utterly chaotic. Once the shooting starts it does not stop till the missions over or you die. It does not have a traditional fog of war and you can only see whats in the direct line of sight of your units. This makes advancing really challenging since you are forced to think about every angle every corner and cover every turn. The game does not have a tutorial so it's worth having a look at the controls since some key bindings are different to traditional RTS which can be frustrating till you figure it out. You can always play the missions on easy to learn but even on normal the AI puts on a decent fight. The controls can be frustrating and its not always obvious what you have selected but it's still worth learning for the sheer pleasure of the challenge this game puts up.

Before I give my review of the game I should let you know that I am an enormous World War 2 history buff, with that in mind there aren't many video games video games that are as specific as this one. Believe me when I say that I have spent hours searching for realistic WW2 games. When I stumbled across MOWAS2 (Men Of War Assault Squad 2) I didn't think it would be so detailed. I'm used to seeing games advertise themselves with super cool graphics, crazy realism, and exciting game play when really they just added filters over the video and made it look better than it actually is. After spending so much time looking for a realistic WW2 game I thought "what the heck, why not give it a try"... and boy would I be surprised. Being able to manage troops on a decently sized map is fun. Especially when you have plenty of options for which units to choose from. I personally enjoy using infantry. Being able to send a squad one place to distract the enemy all while I flank them with another squad. I will admit that the AI can be pretty derpy and overpowered at times. Especially when I have an entire veteran squad and they end up getting mowed down by one crewman on a flak 38. I do recommend playing the campaign first before jumping straight into multiplayer. Even though the campaign is almost all the same material, it really helps teach the mechanics of the game. 
Overall I think this game is great. It has a very active community and there are always lobbies to join. 

Hope to see you on the battlefield!

Yeah, just don't buy it... unless you have patience.

The bad:

First of all, the developer's expect you to buy a £6 (Airborne) DLC just so you can get AI bots to play simple skirmishes against AI on a level playing field. The singleplayer doesn't feature this but instead gives you scenarios for different nations, the scenarios never change, the maps are simply switched. This means that without paying for the DLC, you only have the option to play the same 12 scenarios, with limited units, or play PVP against other players. If you want to skirmish against AI, you better hope you have a friend who owns the airborne DLC.

The developers also expect you to pay for another £6 (Iron Fist) DLC... just so you can view replays. If you want to see your own replay or a friend's replay, you better cough up £6.

On the multiplayer itself, you'll be wasting a lot of time. Most of the people in multiplayer are veterans, there are a lot of decent guys but many will kick you for being new or just completely stomp you out if you don't learn the game quickly. You will rarely be able to actually finish a multiplayer game because rather the host will crash or you will crash, which happens to people in 70% of my games. People crash a lot, so enjoy. It's not even just when you're playing, you'll probably crash while in the lobby because the developers refuse to fix a 4 year old bug which makes players freeze in lobbies (can we get a £6 fix-this-game DLC?).


The good:

On the actual difficulty aspect, this game is pretty rough. If you're not very good at micro, play Company of Heroes because this game is absolutely brutal on poor positioning and such. Though this is one of the reasons I enjoy this game, infantry have tiny healthpools and vehicles have modular damage which means you'll have to repair different parts when a vehicle is hit, if it hasn't been completely destroyed. Individual soldiers can be easily split from their squad and manipulated individually, which means you can reform squads if you need a specialised team or if some of your guys have been blown up. The game is unique in this aspect and you can enjoy some flexibility.

Another saving grace for this game is the modding community. There are tons and tons of mods, some small and some a total overhaul mods which are pretty good. WW1 mods, realism mods, Vietnam and even modern era mods mean that content is not an issue.


Edit: Yup. Game is still trash.

As most played game in my library, it's still amazing to this day. This game to me is like the old Halo is to others; nostalgic and amazing memories. I am still playing this game to this very day. I would never forget all the memories I've had on this game.

And from what I can tell, I am planning on playing it more again with friends, which hasn't happened in over an entire year. So to end this quite emotional review, I'd like to say thank you to the developers for creating this game; its forever amazing community will never get old. Thank You.

[h1] We'll Be in Berlin by Spring [/h1]

*note I have played several of the Men of War games and the previous Assault Squad game*
Men of War: AS 2 is I assume the sequel to the previous Assault Squad game. If you don't know the Men of War series, pretty much it's you control various squads of units throughout the theaters of war during WWII. The Men of War games are known for their fully destructible environments, as well as the ability to directly control units, manage ammo types, commandeer vehicles, and make your own tactics to deal with obstacles. While the other Men of War games are objective-based and have some story, the Assault Squad games are significantly focused more on strategy and controlling armies. In fact, on most of the maps you actually have a currency system that you earn over time as you capture objectives, allowing you to call in more units to help you proceed forward. Unlike the other Men of War games, there are little to no allied units, you are controlling everything. 

The missions are all parallel to each other for each of the factions, which means that for the first mission you will be doing the same thing for each faction, just in a different environment. Despite this, having new vehicles and units that have their own unique weapons provide for different strategies that prevent the maps from feeling completely the same for all factions. The main missions consist of you controlling your squads moving forward and taking over capture points, which unlock more types of units, until you reach the end. The enemy will also send units after you based on how many points you control, so you will be having to defend these points as well. The other missions are varied, from stealth-focused to fortress defense and this kind of variety is much-needed. You'll know what to expect when you play these, and the replay value comes from trying out new strategies and playing on the harder difficulties. If you want a Men of War game, there is no reason not to get this. In fact, I only recommend getting this one. It's an updated version of Assault Squad, and workshop content allows you to play most of the other Men of War games. If you want a squad-based strategy game faithful to the era with chaotic battles, this is for you. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Fully destructible environments with tons of vehicles and weapons to experiment with
[*]Each of the 5 factions are different enough to make you want to play all of them, leading to a lot of content
[*]Significant replay value thanks to it mostly being unscripted 
[*]It's a ton of fun taking control of individual units and making them be COD-level soldiers
[*]Usually competent AI
[*]Good and varied level design and missions
[*]Bots for multiplayer
[*]Workshop content allows you to play almost all previous Men of War games
[/list]
[h1] Cons: [/h1]
[list]
[*]As the fights expand out, managing a larger number of units may become unnecessarily difficult, especially since the auto-move and attack isn't as good as it could be
[*]Technically, every mission is identical for each of the factions, which means no surprises when playing a different one for a different faction
[*]AI can be stupidly incompetent sometimes, specifically with your allies 
[*]It's annoying having new units arriving at the beginning of the map when you're all the way at the end
[*]Little difference from the previous Assault Squad game
[*]Too much water on the Japanese levels
[/list]

[b] Verdict: 8/10 [/b]

A greatly unique game mixing Real Time Strategy with Roleplaying elements along with a slight nudge of third person shooter. To make it more clear, in this game you can select and command units like you do in any RTS game but you can also control each individual soldier or vehicle and for example see its health, stamina and inventory along with the ability to directly control the units with WASD movement and using your mouse to shoot.

The replayability of this game is just incredible and I find myself picking this game up every few months for the last couple of years.

Sadly, 1C Entertainment doesn't know how to replica the success of this game anymore and they just churn out weak "DLC" that doesn't add much besides reskinning some units, I really wish for a proper Assault Squad 3 with more different objectives, more in-depth story telling and perhaps even deeper combat.

I bought this because I've seen some great YouTube videos of this with the Empire at War mod for Star Wars.  I thought I might like to do that too, but I figured I should get a handle on the actual game first.

Well, this game is not really fun.  It's excessively punishing, for one.  Even on the easy difficulties, the AI is pounding you hard and always has the tools needed to, if not outright defeat you, make your afternoon as stressful as possible.  There's no in-game tutorial, but the game doesn't even tell you that.  It just drops you dead into the scenario and waves "good luck".
Choosing units?  You best figure out fast which is which, because you get no information about the units until after you've called for it and it's on your screen.  Didn't know that tank was designed for anti-aircraft?  Too bad, it's yours now.

It often rarely gives you the forces you need to hold the enemy off, expecting you to call for reinforcements.  Which is fine, except the AI has an unlimited amount of them.  Pause in your advance to reorganize and plan your next step and you'll get overwhelmed by exactly whatever enemy unit is the best for killing your current forces, which pushes you back and makes it even harder to get more reinforcements.

And the Editor.   What a train wreck this is.   There is absolutely no help anywhere here.  I spent 20 minutes clicking on the screen with "grass" chosen, and seeing nothing happen.   So I can't even figure out how to make a clear, empty field.   And the game doesn't care if you don't know.

To those who had the help and time to invest in the career of designing stuff for this: kudos.
If you don't want to devote 70 hours a week to this and don't have friends who already know how?  Don't bother.

I really like this game for what it is. The level of detail is amazing for an RTS. The game also looks and runs really good, even on higher settings. However, I have a single, and yet enough of a deal-breaker gripe. I am not good at multiplayer, which is my own darn problem, sure. I was looking for a good singleplayer experience outside of a story/campaign, which is also rather good, by the way. Because of lack of singleplayer skirmish, I cannot recommend this game to anyone who wants what I want.

To be clear, the game is not bad by any means, but I find a certain con of mine unacceptable:

Pros: 

+ Great Gameplay
+ Graphics
+ Attention to/Level of Detail

Con:

- Skirmish for singleplayer is locked behind PAID DLC
- No bots in multiplayer either*

* - I have seen certain discussions both on and off Steam that say there are bots in multiplayer sans DLC, but for the life of me I couldn't figure it out.

This game is amazing for a World War II nerd that enjoys a realistic take on a 'top-down' strategy game. I highly recommend it for it's replay ability. When it comes to the workshop mods it's insane, from creating your own unique battles in the editor mod, to the short skirmishes you can download. There's a lot to choose from, if you want a stealthy mission, taking out AA guns at Normandy, or even changing history. There's *A LOT* of YouTube content too, which can vary from mod reviews to custom maps/scenarios. Of these, I recommend DiplexHeated and theShermanator, as they're the ones that originally had me interested in this game. I haven't delved into the PvP aspect of this game, and that's not because I don't like it, I just never found myself wanting to play it, none-the-less the Multiplayer in this game is fantastic. 

Again, I highly recommend this game for any World War II nerd. I'm very grateful for the developers having created this game, as I've had many fun and hard moments.

TLDR: Unless you like WW2 and got lots of patience to handle disproportionate stupidity in the battlefield, I cannot recommend this game.

MoW 2 is great on many aspects. It's fun to play with friends, factions are fun and somewhat balanced, and overall entertaining RTS gameplay. However, I cannot recommend this game for the sole reason that the AI can be very incompetent on its own and it becomes unbearable on the long-term playthrough. To give an example, I have played MoW Assault Squad 2 with friends since I bought it. It's a blast playing with friends, but something always perturbed me, and that being how the units' AI behave sometimes. I ordered one of my soldiers to throw a frag grenade in a reachable nearby trench, for example, but what he does instead is he unexplicably runs straight to said trench and gets shot to death. Another example is AT guns being incredibly stupid by switching from AP to HE ammo shell when there's a tank less than 10 meters nearby. If you want everything to go according to plan, you'll need to do insane micro managing and manual controlling to your units because the AI can't most things right as intended, and that can be very exhausting. There'll always be thought of something going wrong with simple matters on every next move you do because of how unreliable the AI is.

I love this game a lot with minimal downsides to it besides one, the ostfront DLC. I literally cannot spawn any units in the game. There is no unit spawn menu, so I launch the game and literally cannot spawn in troops and then I get kicked out for not having any units, I've always have been a huge fan of mechanized warfare and the ostfront DLC was great for that very thing, alas you can't exactly have mechanized units if you can't have units to begin with...

Outside of that one annoying small factor this game has all the perfect elements of a good tactical RTS where "who has the most tanks" or "who has the biggest blob" no longer applies to your over all terms of victory, what matters is skill and your tactical knowledge on the battlefield. RTS games like these are hard to come by to say the least, and I am very thrilled with this game.

The base game is a worthwhile experience for the first 40-50 hours, which for most is their money's worth, but the mods keep alive for so much longer. From Warhammer 40k, to the First World War, to the modern day, to simply a load more factions and weapons from the Second World War, there is something for just about everyone here in the modding scene. The engine has its... issues, its based on the Gem Engine, a 32-bit, slightly ancient but still functions (mostly) regardless, and the AI varies from barely servicable to pants-on-head retarded, but despite that it has my love.

Absolutely recommend. The game will make you scream in fury, cry out in rage, then nearly pass out from the dopamine shot as you plant your first PIAT round into the flank of a Konigstiger. 7.5/10 without mods, solid 9/10 with them.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a real time strategy game set in World War II where you can play as five different factions, namely, the USA, the Soviet Union, Japan, Germany and the Commonwealth in various missions while attempting to manage the chaos unfolding on the battlefield and keeping your units alive.

Depending on how you play the game, you might find yourself micromanaging every aspect of the battle, down to the equipment that your infantry is using and even directing their fire yourself through the direct control feature. This is especially useful for units such as AT Guns and Mortars as they may require a little player intervention to help guide their aim.

I play this game primarily as a single player/co-op game and you can play the singleplayer missions in co-op with up to eight players in the co-op Skirmish mode. Co-op has always been one of my favourite parts of the Men of War series and it has resulted in some fun moments such as teaming up with my friends and role-playing divisions, where each of us took command of a bunch of units and split ourselves into roles such as fire support, infantry or mechanised infantry. I also had a friend who wasn't a big fan of the RTS genre but liked that he could command just one unit while transferring everyone else to me.

It is also possible to add bots to some multiplayer modes to enhance your co-op/bot game experience, but they are included in the paid Airborne DLC which is a bit of a bummer so if you want, you could pick it up for cheap when the game goes on sale like I did.

I would recommend this game to fans of World War II games or those who are looking for a strategy game that takes a more realistic and tactical approach to the genre. Additionally, with Steam Workshop integration, you can install a variety of mods that can change up your overall experience and the developers have provided development tools that you can use to create your own scenarios, missions and content.

If you're coming from Assault Squad 1 like myself, look at 2 as an upgrade. For new players who have never played Assault Squad 1 before, get 2 instead. It can be overwhelming at first but once you get the hang of things, it's a pretty fun, yet challenging RTS to play.

I love this game, it has everything I could ever want in a WWII RTS. It has immersive gameplay that can get you trapped for hours and hours playing over fun campaign missions using unique units and countries. The only complaint I have with this game is that most of the missions have the same format when you change countries. For example, mission 3 Lenningrad on the Soviet Union faction is a mission where you find yourself defending against an enemy armored column for 8 waves. This mission is fun, but once you switch over to another country like Germany or The Commonwealth, mission 3 for every other country is also a defense against an armored column.

*Subjective as hell*
After Soldiers: Heroes of World War II this game ... hell no. I was a bit confused about it. But then i got it. (I`ll be talking bout story and avaliable companies , i will not touch upon online part of the game because i havent tried it)
There are campaigns for each nation - 8 missions in total (ALL THE SAME for each nation , the only change is units) , if you try out one campaign , you basically have played them all. Each mission , (excluding a couple) is just a massacre. Most of the game scenery is just THE MORE UNITS THE BETTER. On one hand it looks good but on the other its kinda lame, and thats what i hated the most, because my first acquaintance with this series started at Man of War: Diversants 2, where you had a small squad at hand and you had to make due with it and thats what i like the most. Going back to Assault Squad 2 i can also sau that every mission was dragged for way to long. If you want to buy it then by all means Wait For A Discount. If you dont have Soldiers: Heroes of World War II then id suggest you buy it.
///После Soldiers: Heroes of World War II эта игра... ну уж нет. Я был немного в недоумении чего и к чему. Но потом понял. *Далее пойдет рассказ об компаниях, сетевую игру не расматриваю ибо не довелось.*
Компании для каждой нации - это 8 мисий(ОДИНАКОВЫХ для разных наций, просто в разной обвертке в виде техники и юнитов), если поиграете в 1 компанию увидите их все. Каждая , по своей сути за исключением 2-ух, мисия - бойня. В этой игре большинство всего сделано на массовость. С одной стороны это не плохо и смотриться... Но для меня это был минус, ибо началось мое знакомство с серией с игры В тылу врага: Диверсанты 2, где у тебя были небольшие отряды и ты должен был выкручиваться как мог и это мне нравилось! Возращаясь к Assault Squad 2 можно еще сказать, что мисии довольно таки затянуты. Если и покупать, то строго по скидке! Если у вас нету Soldiers: Heroes of World War II, то лучш уже взять ее.

Not a bad game at all, but 8.5 hours in and I'm no better than when I started. The learning curve is most certainly cliff-like, as I spend most of my time in firefights wondering what the fuck is going on as the units I'm moving suddenly stop advancing towards the new cover spot and just start shooting out in the open before getting mowed down.
Maybe a tutorial mission of some sort would not go amiss, and a ramping up of difficulty rather than throwing you in to the thick of things would make it a bit easier to enjoy.
If you're really good at company of heroes already and want something even more in depth, I think this would be good for you. If you are not a micro-inclined gamer at all and have stupid fingers and are not willing to spend a lot of time learning how to make them smart, I probably wouldn't get this game.
Note: if someone has a recommendation for people who are new, please leave it in the comments, because I would like to enjoy this game rather than just quit out of frustration.
