I would recommend this game, it is an absolutely great addition to the Men of War series. Here are a list of the pros and cons of the game, starting out with the pros.

Pros:
-Excellent mod support (Simple and easy)
-Great micro-management that is optional that adds much depth to the game
-Multiplayer really brings out the game
-Large variety of weapons
-Wide ability to interact with the environment
-Has much potential to do anything you want with it
-GEM editor

Cons:
-Universally copied and pasted missions from MoW:AS
        -Singleplayer is not enjoyable to the extent it could be
-Engine not funny optimized
-Developers are getting closer to forgetting the game (No updates, which makes sense)
-Overall could be improved

MoW:AS2 is a great buy, just take into account these factors before you do.

Idk whether to give a positive review or negative review. I'll be neutral on this. The game is good overall. Improved graphic,texture quality. More units both infantry and tanks. But what's lacking is the objective in mission play. In single player mode you will find that almost every faction has the similar objective just in diffrent environment. So it gets kinda boring after playing the game for awhile without real objective. However it does have more options in multiplayer mode. So if you are kin to online host games than this is pretty much worth the play. But if you are more into single player with various and more challenging missions than this isn't the game for you. Personally i liked the graphic details so I'll go with a Yes.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 brings out a total different vibe from the more popular Company of Heroes. Each individual soldier can act as an agent and the micromanagement is all up to the player as they see fit. The game has super crazy explosions, and the units can be used in every tactical way if used correctly. Overtime, you learn how to run your own simulation with the units you select whether it be infantry or armor.

Though, one things for sure, you can't win a game unless you have infantry as the backbone of the army. Therefore, armor can only get you so far. GAME 7/10, MULTIPLAYER 2/10. EDITOR 1/10  The singleplayer is fun, however it is too micro-managy... stuck on multiple missions where you simply dont get enough resources to stop the mass spamming of enemy units on your position. the AI are very dumb, a tank can literally roll 2 feet away from it, and the infantry doesnt have the sense to pull out an anti tank grenade and kill the tank, it will just dumbly stand there until the tank shoots it, or you manually tell it to kill the tank. tanks are even worse.. their targeting range is terrible, and usually gets outshot by a tank it should easily crush, simply because the enemy tank parks just outside of the AI firing range and will shoot it until it dies, unless you manually tell your tank to fire at the enemy tank.. there are multiple other major issues the AI has, and i care not to go into further detail on the AI. and lastly.. the editor... absolutely a waste of time.. crashes 80% of the time, and when it does work it will randomly crash while editing..

on the positive side, if you can get some friends together to play some multiplayer co-op maps, it is quite fun, but other than that, multiplayer is not very good.

I have had great experiences playing this game, MoW has hit the perfect spot between Commandos 2 & Company of Heroes and it's certainly a must have if you enjoy games like Company of Heroes/Dawn of War, but are after more strategy, realism and a slower paced, less "arcady" RTS. 

One of the perks that comes with buying this game is the great community/player base that releases amazing and well crafted mods, missions & maps that make MoW:AS2 feel new and fresh every month or so. 
Only gripe I have is with the AI pathfinding that can at times make weird travel decisions, so some babysitting while moving tanks and other vehicles is required. Other than that, the game runs perfectly smooth, looks stunning and will most likely keep you busy for years to come, as it has with me.

This game is a ensemble of really good ideas. 

Small unit RTS with tanks and fairly accurately portrayed armor penetration over distance and through obstacles

Time to kill is potentially instantaneous quick for everything, keeping you on your toes.

The importance of positioning and ammunition rewards fast and decisive engagements.

Line of fire, line of sight, concealment and fog of war. You sneak through foliage, and so can your opponent.

Looting and inventory: Wanna trade a bren for a .50cal? Do it! Desperately need an AT grenade? Go find a dead SMG soldier!

Multiplayer and co-op!

Some impressive mods!

Downsides: absolutely no in-game explanations, single player missions are essentially copy pasted for each nation, plethora of features are way too complex for the AI to handle, buildings get damaged extremely easily which can throw off map design by reducing available cover, smoke grenades are a missed opportunity.

I wish there was also a way to assign a squad to loot an area for their ammo types instead of having to search individual cadavers.

Скажу честно и прямо.
Игра интересная, много модификация которые делают игру серьёзнее и реалистичнее так и наоборот, казуальнее и веселее.
Одиночная компания честно говоря на один раз и но в целом сделана и задумана интересно со своими сложностями.

Мультиплеер сделан и оптимизирован хорошо даже играя 8х8, да и в целом людей сидит достаточно.

Но самая главная часть этой игры это её редактор где ты сам себе хозяин, захотел чтобы японцы воевали с немцами? Пожалуйста, японский экипаж в т34? Получите и распишитесь, Американцы перестреливаются с Англичанами, вот же смотри уже начали, редактор ограничен только вашей фантазией и умением хотя бы немного почитать и разобраться в нём, хотя мне хватило 10 минут чтобы устроить зарубу.

В целом 9 из 10, 6 баллов из которых за редактор, ибо здесь он сделан шикарно за что многие и любят эту игру.

Fun World War 2 themed RTS game.

You can control each individual unit, and give them the loadout you want by stealing it off the enemy's (or ally's) dead corpse. Want a machine gun for your rifleman? No problem, just give him that sweet MG 42 and watch him spray that gun like an 9 year old playing COD for the first time.

Want your guys to build sandbags to sit behind? Sure, set it up on a hill with a machine gun behind the sandbags, and watch him mow down platoons of enemy infantry.

Want some puny Sherman tanks to take out a Tiger 1? That's do-able, just re-enact the movie Fury.


But sometimes, you'll question if you conscripted total fucking retards, as they fail to shoot the enemy in front of them, try to "throw" a grenade by RUNNING TO THE ENEMY MACHINE GUNNER, OR YOUR SHERMAN EXPOSE THEIR SIDE ARMOUR AND GET DESTROYED BY A TINY PAK 38.

But overall, pretty nice game.

When I bought the deluxe edition for AS-2, I was paying more not only because I loved the previous games in the franchise, but because I loved what potential AS-1 had presented us with, especially considering the many great mods avalible for the original. But more than that, I was buying the sequel to one of my favorite games of all time.

Needless to say, I haven't been impressed. In fact, my experience with AS2 has been beyond disappointment. Given the time from the early beta stage to now, and including the push-back of the release date multiple times, I've found that this game has not only been a waste in terms of what potential it had, but you are literally paying for a $34.00 overhaul patch by buying this game.

The biggest improvements since AS-1 have been:

1. Multiplayer, which lags often, and depends on who is better at storming a place with infantry and light vehicles. Tanks are, very rarely fielded. The gameplay is repetitive, and balance issues come and go.

2. The Super-Pershing and a few tank models. Yeah, they look a little more "smooth," but then you can take a peek at everything else. Everything else is literally recycled from the previous game.

3. Multi-core support. I haven't noticed a difference.


The things I'd thought I was going to see:

1. A little bit of variety in the infantry. Yeah, they don't even have new models or textures. It's the exact same thing from the previous title, rehashed a bit for a few more "Breeds," which you can make by simply opening the editor and reassigning a few traits, weapons, and items. There are a few more voices thrown in for the American and English soldiers, but there is still plentiful cut-and-paste from the previous game. Oh, and the voice acting is horrific for the most-part.

2. Better textures. The dirt looks beautiful. A few tanks look better. But, for everything else, it all is recycled from the last game. The buildings aren't different. The uniforms aren't different. The mass majority of vehicles aren't different.

3. Better gameplay. Yeah, no. In fact, they took away the feature where you could unload your guns. The AI is a little more "Cover-seeking," so they are no longer inherently stupid. However, you still have to pack up millions of bullets so they can fend for themselves without running dry.

4. Differences between faction weapons. I'll admit, I was expecting more realistic performance out of the guns for each faction. But, all rifles are pretty much the same, the Thompson isn't much different from an MP-40, the Grease-Gun is treated like a 9-mm, and overall, you're just going to go for an MG-42 if you want rate of fire; the browning if you want less reloading; or the BAR/FG-42 if you want less unloading. There isn't much of an accuracy or damage difference. Line up soldiers with every faction's rifle; they fire and reload at the exact, same times, with the exception of the enfield rifleman. There should be a difference. The action on a Mosin is completely different from a 98' or a Springfield.

5. Models and textures. Yeah, about 10 vehicles look better. But the mass majority of the others still look copy/paste. If I wanted to copy/paste vehicles, I'd make a mod for that.

Can I say I recommend this game? No. For $34.00, hell no. It's nowhere near being worth that kind of money, and I'm losing to faith to tell myself that "yeah, it'll improve as they get closer to the full release." It's been in Early Access for quite some time now. Before that, there was beta. They have had the time to improve the game. Yet, I have only seen them trying to get it into a playable state every few weeks, while leaving us high and dry in every other aspect. Maybe if it were $10.00 DLC for AS1, it'd be worth it. But as a standalone game, let alone a Sequel, it's not just a cheap re-release with nothing new to offer, but it's a complete waste of money.

I've already learned from one other game that pulled the same "Beta limited-content" trick. ArmA 3. Overall, that game was a complete disappointment. There was very little content added into the beta, there was very little content added into the main game, and countless patches treated the post-final release like it was (and still is) in the early-access stage. AS2 is mirroring this tactic, and foreshadows disappointment.

I have a feeling they're going to just decide to "leave it to the modders," as ArmA 3 did, and while mods are often well done, they are not only far from uniform in quality and not designed by a common party, but that's a cheap way of copping-out of extensive work. Work that this game seriously needs if it is to hold the number "2" after Assault Squad.

A better name for this would be "Assault Squad: MEGAPATCH." If you feel like disagreeing, then pull up the AS1 editor and the AS2 editor. Put down one of every model. Test the game, see what happens; you'll learn that I'm right, because this is exactly how I tested it. I'm not making these claims without evidence. There is no difference between these games except for the mulitplayer.


Do keep in mind; this review is for a $34.00 product. It is intended to reflect and aid you, the viewer, in determining whether or not you will "get what you pay for." The answer to that is no, "No, you won't."

I SINCERELY HOPE THAT THE FINAL RELEASE PROVES MY FEARS TO BE WRONG, AND RENDERS THIS REVIEW TO BE OUTDATED. SHOULD THAT BE THE CASE, I WILL GLADLY CHANGE MY REVIEW AND HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE GAME. SHOULD MY FEAR THAT THIS GAME OFFERS NO "CHANGE" WORTHY OF A SEQUEL BE CONFIRMED AT FINAL RELEASE, I WILL NO LONGER DO BUSINESS WITH DIGITAL-MIND-SOFT.

Do know; I won't be alone in that regard.




[July 19, 2014] UPDATE!

Ok; so since the game's release, there has been little to nothing improved upon since I had written this review. The "priority" for the team has only been multiplayer. There has been no increase in content. There has been no more bang for the buck. Digital-Mind-Soft has charged their community for a mere patch, and has done nothing to back the quality of the game except tamper with multiplayer mechanics, and not even to the extent that significantly alters gameplay in any way.

Do you have money to waste, and want to support a dishonest development project? Then don't spend money. Please.

Stop giving companies the motivation to screw over their customers and to default on their promises. It's been months, and there aren't even any new "Humanskins" in the game. Let me say right now: It takes 10 MINUTES OR LESS TO CREATE A NEW "SKIN" USING PAINT.NET.

With the time they've taken to add "boards" to Multiplayer, I could have created the entire Italian Army with a modeling program; sadly, that's 3DS-MAX, a program that the 2014 edition of, costs upwards of $3,400 to own.




[August 26 2014] UPDATE!

Playing through the editor a bit, one of the first things I checked were the models. What can I say about them? Three new models; all Crusader Tanks. The model has been significantly improved, with the Crusader looking more streamlined and smooth than before. It looks good. Not only that, but there are 2 more Crusaders; a 40mm Anti-Air crusader, and a 20mm Anti-Air crusader. These, too, look good. But nonetheless, Japanese vehicles still look as though they are made out of cardboard, and there haven't been any other model updates added.

Most importantly, the soldiers still have the same skins as in the previous title; the lack of effort in this category is appaling. Do bare in mind; Assault Squad was a 2009 game. This means that the soldier's skins are 5 Years old. You can learn to create professional 3D models in half that time. Given that this much time has progressed, one would and should expect more from a company charging full-price for a "patchwork" game.

Men Of War AS2 > Company Of Heroes 2.
Epic Game 602/101

Me and my mate bought this after exhausting our pointless lives and any reasons to sustain them on Company of Heroes 2, and that's the game I'm comparing it to.

✔️WHAT I LIKE:

- Good variety of units.
- Tends to be more fast paced unlike CoH2.
- *autistic screeching* holy sh*t you can actually take control of individual soldiers and tanks and shoot enemies yourself!
- Infantry seems to be more deadly and pose more of a threat to tanks than in CoH. Firefights go by quick. Although the soldiers do seem to instantly die from a fly landing on their shoulder.
- Explosions actually kill infantry. It always annoyed me how in Company of Heroes 1/2 a blast from a 150mm howitzer would barely scratch enemies 2 metres away from the explosion. Mainly only units directly in the explosion would get killed, not the tw*ts around it. In this game the explosion actually has a blast radious, at least against the infantry, and it actually feels like a threat against infantry. Your howitzers do not feel underpowered. 

❌WHAT I DON'T LIKE:

- It looks mediocre.
- The UI is terrible and ugly.
- The dodgy controls in this game make it feel like it's in alpha or something.
- The mortar feels very weak and incredibly inaccurate. It's like throwing firecrackers during a tornado.
- I had times where my 122mm tank would struggle to penetrate the side of a standard Panzer, so the 'hit detection' feels dodgy.
- The German and American tanks seem to be noticably better which kinda leads to unbalanced gameplay.
- The British seem to not have a good heavy tank? The most powerfull one is 77mm I think. Seriously? I guess it's historically accurate but it seems to put the Brits at a considerable disadvantage. This leads to even more unbalanced gameplay, where you struggle to kill asingle Tiger with your dinky little 75mm Cromwells.
- All maps feel exactly the same. Every map is very open. There are no maps with islands you can cross to only via bridges, or tight crossing etc. for some cool chokepoint gameplay.

🏁VERDICT:

All in all, I like the game, it definitely is a good alternative to Company of Heroes, but ultimately it lacks the overall quality and polish of CoH so I'd go for that anyway.

TL;DR;
this is just MOW: AS with some extra maps. only get if on sale, you're interested in learning how to mod and don't know where to start, or want some decent multiplayer. 

easily one of, if not the, most overrated WWll strategy games out there. i have countless hours on the first MOW: AS, and i think that game is ass. I copped this game for about $3 on sale and I have to say that if I paid a penny more I would have refunded after the first hour. This game is what MOW:AS should've been and isn't even much of an improvement. 

If you have played MOW:AS, or any other MOW, don't waste your money on this one. I was expecting many improvements based off of the first game, but the devs don't even attempt to reskin the game at all, they use the exact same maps and throw in some ridiculous missions where there are new (but mostly unimpressive) maps. Same exact skins and uniforms, same exact voices, and for the most part same exact maps and missions. RobZ Realism Mod helps a good bit in the skins and uniforms, and there are some pretty good map mods/mods in general which I will talk about in a sec.

SO, maps and missions. As I said, there are new maps and unlike the first AS the missions on the maps vary. Many of the missions have different parts, such as the first USA mission, you defend for a bit and counter attack. This was very enjoyable and kept every mission from being the same, boring thing. However, a couple missions in and everything gets boring. I know this is a thing in every MOW game I've played, so maybe the series just isn't for me, but the AI has absolutely no real AI. They just mindlessly fart out and throw their resources at you, you just have to learn the pattern at which the big bad tanks and howitzers come out and where to put your men and how to use your special abilities (airstrikes etc). The difficulty setting only changes how much damage your soldiers take when they're shot, not AI strategy. If your goal is to attack, they sit there, reinforcements come and attempt to counterattack periodically, and for every "line of defense" captured, the enemy throws more of their advanced stuff at you, and the more big guns you have to get through. Not only speaking of AI strat, but this is hardly a strat game period. You can sneak through bushes, pop up and shoot everybody, maybe drop some airborne behind lines and make some chaos while you send an assault squad up, but that's about it. The maps are far too narrow to do any real flanking manevours, and this was a problem in AS1 too. It was a problem in every MOW I've played, so maybe the series just isn't for me. 

I CAN SAY, however, the multiplayer in the game is fun, the community is still bustling, and there are plenty of mods out there to make the game a tad bit enjoyable, however good luck finding many mods that are compatible with each other. I can also say that the editor for the game is very extensive and imo it would be great for any novice modder or somebody who wants to try it out.  If you have never played a MOW before, want the experience, and this game is on sale, go ahead and give it a go. 

Also this MOW is still far superior to MOW: Vietnam. That was probably the worst game I've ever played.

Have to say I had more fun with this game that Company of Heroes 2. Assault squad 2 feels more realistic, with each unit having its own inventory and such, the different amount of weapons and vehicles.

Some downsides are AI pathing is a little weak. You can order a truck to go across the map just to find it got stuck on a fence post, or for some reason just stopped halfway there.

Missions are fun, not in any order, some are stealth, some are more capture the point style, but the latter wears out easily since its capture the first, second and third line of defence but the 3rd line of defence is normally always guarded by arty and heavy tank guns, meaning its a slog every time to get to the end, sending units into the grinder. 

Basically never send infrantry in without support, and never send armor in without support, or it will be pretty easily killed, since most soldiers have AT grenades. Repairing vehicles for use is a great mechanic to have in a game, playing as Russia for example you can build up an armor devision by fixing all the broken down German tanks you find still servicable 

In all 8/10

The message I left for my refund request sums up the problems I had with this game. I feel like there is a gem of a game under it all, but it is buried deep. It was as follows:

I was expecting company of heroes type gameplay with more in depth controls and more realism. I have been wanting this game for years and have watched gameplay videos on YouTube and trailers as well. It looked like the WW2 game of my dreams! Instead, the controls were overly complicated and the one tutorial mission was hidden under bonus missions and the control tips went away way too fast. It was just a regular mission on which they slapped some text over to quickly tell you controls. Also, the in game tutorial videos won't even load, which is a problem others had on the discussion forums, leading me to have to find them on YouTube. Between watching the videos and testing stuff in game, it'll take me hours to actually learn how to play. By then, I'll be out of the refund period without having actually played the game whilst knowing the controls to see if I like it! All in all, the years of waiting were a disappointment, and have led to my first refund. I have some other games that I actually know I'll keep on Steam after buying during this sale, like Running With Rifles, which had a demo that I loved. If the devs read this, include a demo with an in-depth tutorial so we can get a good feel of the game!

TL:DR - Good strategy game with Direct Control, no bots in base game

WW2 Strategy game that allows you to command and direct control a large variety of interesting units. (yes, DIRECT CONTROL)

Singleplayer missions aren't very interesting, more of a tutorial and a showcase of the units, rather than a campaign. This game shines in multiplayer PvP, or against bots with friends.

You do not receive the ability to use bots in the base game, you must purchase the Airborne DLC in order to use them. Fortunately, you don't need to have the DLC to play games with bots in them, it is only needed to host matches with bots, which is useful if you are short on cash and a friend already has the DLC.

The modding community is great, with plenty of well-made mods that greatly improve gameplay.

Overall, this is a pretty good game with interesting mechanics and fun gameplay, and is great to play with a few friends

this is one of the few staples of real time strategy games, holds its merits regardless of age. Having the ability to (literally) control every unit under your command makes for great gameplay and some cheeki breeki tactics. Men Of War Assault Squad 2 makes for rich and varying gameplay with a large variety of mods (of quite high quality) and also comes with an editor mode granting you the ability to create any scene and scenario you can think of to satisfy your deviant militaristic minds.

overall i would most certainly suggest this game to any history buff or rts enthusiast!

I can go on for hours why I love this game, first of all its a WW2 strategy game, which in of itself makes it perfect, you can play as the USA, UK, USSR, Germany, Japan, or the DLC faction (another Germany), and the differences for each faction shines bright in the game, especially with the faction specific special units that cost medals (10 medals per game in vanilla), and the huge workshop with way more mods to be found, the game is perfect for WW2 and Strategy lovers out there. Controlling your units puts you straight into the combat (not a first person perspective but you can manually shoot a selected soldier or vehicle) and commanding a huge group of soldiers and tanks is great fun. But its not without its downsides.

The Ai in the game can be buggy and sometimes just freezes and stops spawning things for awhile, but other times it runs fine (some mods fix this issue, but some make it worse so I wont touch too much on this) and another problem is that you need to learn what each unit is in order to use it proper, but this can be either researched on the internet or from trial and error, and you cant have to many mods enabled at the same time, but most times the pros outweigh the cons, I have great fun in this game and I'm sure many others do too, and I felt I needed to express some downsides to the game before touching on it deeper.

This game is great fun, with some friends or online players you can turn the game into serious competitive plays, or stupid fun or even messing around, there was this one time where me and a friend of mine built "The great wall", made entirely of sandbags, we set the score to the max with no timer so the game lasts as long as it could, and tried our best to hold it against the Germans, us being the Americans, we threw everything we had to keep the wall up, repairing damages and constantly restocking troops, armour, guns, etc, we had a blast, with friends the game can change so much, you can get a lot of laughs out of it, after "The great wall" was finished we kept joking that America was completely "out of half-tracks and ranger squads" as we used so many during the fight to keep the wall up, I loved that match and plan on making more stupid challenges like that in the future, while also playing the game normally time to time, to get the original experience again, I recommend this game not just for fun gameplay elements, graphics, and the fact its a WW2 strategy game, but for the funny, abnormal, and weird experiences it can offer, especially with friends at your side.

[h1][b]A Must-Try for any strategy/WW2 fan[/b][/h1]

Excelent strategy option for those that are fans of WW2, incredibly fun and challeging when played with friends, requiring organization and a lot of thinking from all to find and pplay the best tactics. Campaign missions may take hours on harder levels, which will require effort and patient, but if accomplished, it will have been fun and even rewarding. 

[h1]Superior than other WW2 startegy games in my opinion[/h1]. Missions are well built and fun, DLC brings more missions for an affordable price. 

Multiplayer can also be fun if played with friends and players willing to put some effort in it. It may be very repetitive though, shifting the player towards the campaign missions as well as mods ([b]Another extra for the game, mods normally work well, and there is a fairly large number of them on Steam[/b]).

Loading screens may take a little too long, and the habilty of joining a match after it was already started, it's not present, which is a big negative point. [u] If your connection drops and you want to join your friends again, you will have to re-start the match.[/u]

Still a great game though, definitely worthy.

I've been playing this game for years and I still come back to it.  The base game is fantastic, even better with the workshop mods, and I love the realistic aspects of this RTS.  Taking "direct control" of a single unit, having them prone and sneaking past some enemies, and blowing up a tank with a bazooka from its flank is so satisfying.  Being able to control a single unit instead of just selecting and clicking around is easily one of the best features of this game, unlike so many other RTS games that I've played like Age of Empires and Company of Heroes.  However, that does cause quite a bit of micromanaging at times.  This game has so much to offer and I highly recommend it.  Just be warned, on heroic difficulty(singleplayer), battles can last for hours before even coming close to finishing.

This is without a doubt one of the greatest RTS games of all time. I personally love any game that is WWII related but this game is something else. You could sit here for hours creating your own battles in the editor, play through the campaign or play the brilliant multiplayer mode. However if WWII doesn't cream your cracker some of the amazing mods for this game let you play in the cold war, the modern era, even star wars. The level of detail in this game is incredible as well, you can customise each individual soldiers inventory, tanks combat is highly realistic meaning you need to plan your movements carefully and each faction has many realistic and faction specific units which are all unique in their own way. Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in RTS or WWII however I would stay away from all of the DLC apart from Airborne as Airborne adds in AI bots for multiplayer (Something that should have been in the base game) and 1 new stealth skirmish mission for each faction, the rest of the DLC is just poor quality cash grabs.

Personally one of my favourite RTS game seeing as I grew up with the franchise. Man of War is a great tactical WW2 real time strategy game, This game has engaging game play and stills holds up with its RTS mechanics, It also implements the option of personally controlling units and playing as them in the third person adding a new refreshing option for games. Also the WW2 timeframe adds for interesting units and weapons with a variety of tanks and infantry, although as time has passed the graphics have become quite lacklustre, The game is still releasing DLC although these DLC aren't up to the quality of the main game and maybe not worth the purchase. I recommend this game as a more casual RTS and for more beginner players of the genre.

This is an amazing game, especially with the many wonderful mods on Workshop. Although I enjoy Company of Heroes, Men of War gives me more, for example, being able to play as the Japanese, and playing in the Pacific, in general. 

It's much more tactical than CoH, and each soldier has his own inventory, a name, and they can be placed individually behind any sort of cover. In CoH the land formation counts for nothing, as the enemy can shoot right through it, however, in MoW that's not so.

Men of War feels more like chess, while Company of Heroes feels like checkers. Both're very fun, but have different levels of depth.

Men of War, especially the Valour and Robz mods, are so incredibly enjoyable, they add even more layers to the vanilla counterpart.

Co-op is another fantastic aspect of the game, I've spent most of my time in this arena.

A duel-wielding thumbs up for MoW!

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a retro, squad-based strategy game. In the game you will be able to choose from different campaigns, either the American, German, British, or Japanese. There's a lot of replay value in these missions. The game does take a while to get used to, but if you play a lot of strategy games you should be able to pick it up fairly quickly. The online community is great and fun, but I do not know how active it is now. Overall, I recommend this game if you are looking for a challenging strategy game.

There are so very few words to describe the joy I feel sending dozens of squads to attack the dug-in german defenses near Bastogne with several squadrons of Shermans supporting them. Sending those troops into the teeth of hell to capture the first of several defense phases and coming up short with but four tanks of the original twenty. This defensive wave wasn't even supported by the menacing 88mm guns or the nebelwehver rocket artillery behind the third defense phase, in the final objective.

The year is 1944, and the USMC and the Japanese SLNF are fighting the Waffen SS in Saipan. Meanwhile, the British Expeditionary Force is wrestling control of North Africa from the Red Army.

Yes, this is basically what happens in Hearts of Iron IV when you turn off historical focuses and let the AI run amok. Except, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is the RTS version of the battles that happened in the field. Of course, those battles are not from the campaign mode, but the skirmish mode.

Compared to other similar WW2 RTS games, people might notice that Men of War: Assault Squad 2 might have clunkier and more unstable engine and maybe dated graphics. But, not all WW2 RTS lets you to take [i]direct control[/i] of your individual units from tanks, infantry, to artillery. Not trusting the AI to handle where the tank would stay and shoot from? Press E to move, aim, and shoot with the tank by yourself.

Also, bonus points for the volume of sound effects. If you're not careful, you might violate your ears because you forgot to lower the volume when the epic artillery duel between the 122mm Soviet guns and the American "Long Tom" starts, or a swarm of Japanese infantry charges on a fortified German position.

Not satisfied with the limited nations roster and some mechanics of the game? There's lots of mods in the Steam Workshop. The mod I'm using adds many nations and equipment to the existing nations' roster. Now you can recreate the British Invasion of France in 1940, the Second Hungarian-Romanian War of 1942, or the Chinese Invasion of Poland in 1939!

Not to mention the mission editor bundled with the game. Not satisfied by the missions and maps provided by the game or the mods? Make your own! Create your own maps, add building, place victory points and other objects, and just maybe, add those new objects and weapons added by mods for the editor!

So, my friend might not exaggerate when he said, "This is the HOI4 of WW2 RTS", cos it does really feel like you're fighting one of those wacky battles between the Germans and Americans against the Franco-Soviet Alliance.

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a good game, although lacking a few satisfactory components. 
This game has well constructed maps which can be utilised strategically, rather than a bunch of shoot out shitfests, and the encorporation of different units to fufiill this. Examples of this include the map Canyon where there is a centre to contest as well as the side chokepoints to battle through for the goal of winning. 

Men of War AS2 also has a good range of modes, including Assault Zones and Combat - Assault Zones is like domination where you contest particular flag points, combat is the destruction of enemy units to a particular score. 

I really enjoy the vehicle mechanics although I think that they are lacking airforce capabilities to bring out a full, WW2 experience.

The satisfactory components that are missing are:
Intelligent AI - The AI you command can do stupid shit resulting in their deaths like standing up to go somewhere instead of crawling and running into the open when you select a grenade target instead of just throwing it. 

GLITCHES: There are a number of glitches I have encountered including the inability to activate a mod (literally in the options you can, it just wont work) and sometimes the game randomly crashes saying "File will be executed" or something like that.

This game is one of my favorite games, and will be for a long time, and if you have ever played age of empires 1 or 2 (idk about 3) then it is very similar to that, except no building, just fighting. But it does have some bugs and glitches, but said bugs and glitches are sometimes very funny, like when you ram a goliath under a tank, especially a modded tank, because some mods dont have the correct weight on tanks, then detonate it, the tank will usually go to space, and me and my friends have had a good laugh with that, but there still are some cons, like the direct control, which could be better, especially with infantry, you can always tell if your friend is controlling a soldier because they will most of the time be moonwalking or walking sideways. Then there are the missions, singleplayer and skirmish, the tank defense mission and the normal defense missions are the best i would say, because i just like defending, but for every nation, they are pretty much the same, the only differences are the map design, and the units, but the goal and the point is the same. The price is also a bit much but this game goes on sale often, so i would recommend this game, but a lot of people dont like having random people in their games, but i usually dont have a problem with this because i only play with my friend (soon to be friends). If you like semi-real WW2 strategy games, then Men of War is it, but if you are going to get it, wait until it goes on sale, because ive seen this game on sale for about 6 bucks all DLCs once, i think it was memorial day, but idk. So yes, good game.

I don't think I've ever played a game with so many possibilities as this underrated masterpiece of a strategy game. The mods alone allow it to be a hundred games in one: Star Wars, Warhammer 40k, The Cold War, modern combat, and so many more. One of the best features is the ability to revert to a previous save, which has made SO many mods available.

Now, I'm not a very avid multiplayer player of this game. When the game, on launch, gives you the "editor" option, it is NOT just a normal editor. There, you can actually play out battles, and in a format that's more or less the normal game!

Just a few tips for the editor: 
Numpad 0-9 is to switch YOUR team
F1=Gameplay Mode
F2=Editting mode
F3=Somewhere in between
On the menu on the left, below the part where you spawn things, there's a menu. It allows you to do such things as switch movement and firing modes, but MOST IMPORTANTLY it allows you to change the team of a unit you have selected.
(if you switch the team of a vehicle with the crew in it, the crew will bail and be the wrong team. God I hate when I forget that!)

Mods I would suggest are: Rising Sun, GSM Fields of Honor, Robz Realism, Red Rising, UMW 40kand valour. Some are admittedly better than others, but nothing is perfect.

Aircraft in the game are.. Well they suck. It's a shame saying it, but they don't even exist in most missions. There is a good, good reason for that. However, some mission mods actually do let air support actually work!

Basically, buy this game. If you want to use the editor, get good at it. It won't be much fun until you get the basics, but after that it's unrivaled.

 Whilst multiplayer is very rewarding experience with it's vast array of maps and mods, it can 

be annoying at times; Unbalanced teams, players with poor connection, AI bugs to name a 

few- but don't let this deter you as it's still a lot of fun! The GEM level editor is a powerful (And 

fun) tool that is a perfect edition to the base game that allows for a near endless amount of 

tinkering, map making and scripting. The workshop is filled with all kinds of mods such as: 

Realism, unit skins, new vehicles, missions, ect. (you can find even more on Mod db).  
______________________________________________________________
Below are pros and cons I have found in MOWAS2


   PROS: -Wonderful game engine
             -Excellent graphics
             -Difficult but rewarding multiplayer Gameplay
             -An editor that allows you to do anything you want from designing maps, level 
             building, even goofing around
             -Can run the vanilla game on a integrated graphics card (Be sure to lower the settings)

CONS: -Some mods when combined- can glitch out the game
            -The AI can sometimes be a bit stubborn, so you have to learn how to work with it
            -To play offline against bots, the Airborn DLC is required

MOW2 is an INTENSE WW2 RTS with a lot to offer to anyone who likes a more light kind of approach to WW2 gaming. This is not the realistic WW2 strategy game where you have to think about supply lines, psychology and grand strategy. This is about engagements in a limited space, house-to-house fighting and ability to make a fast tactical decision. You have to choose the  right troops, vehicles and guns as the attacker or defender. Then you have to coordinate your different troops and guns into a battle force that has a chance of winning. 

In this game, 10 soldiers with rifles can die to a single soldier who ambushes them with a fast SMG. Give a longer range and two riflemen can wipe out a squad of SMG soldiers. You get the point. Theres a vast range of different troops and machinery to choose from. All major factions of WW2 are an option.

The graphics are of course a bit dated but still good enough. Sounds are good and often realistic. Its so-so if I would recommend this for single player gamers (the campaigns can be a bit lacking in atmosphere and AI could use some help) but hell yes I recommend this for the multiplayer types. I have had countless white-knuckled and adrenaline fueled bouts against my friends, and victories have felt like victories. Losses have felt like losses and some more. If you like a fast small-scale RTS wargame with a bit of realism and a lot of situations and frantic snap-decisions ... get this game today, make one of your friends get it and then go 1v1. Or play online with a lot of people. You probably will not regret it.

Otherwise the games great if u dedicate enough time to learn it and all the neeshes that come with it. 9/10 Would German again.

After over 100 hours on this game, I can say that Men of War Assault Squad 2 is one of the best WW2 real-time strategy games on steam. The campaign and multiplayer missions are okay, but the real fun of the game is the editor and scenarios. MOWAS 2 reaches all audiences with its gameplay. If you like difficult, tense RTS style battles where you can command a squad of units, and slowly gain more land and man power over the course of the battle, MOWAS 2 has you covered. But, if you enjoy spawning hundreds or thousands of units and watching them fight, this game is also capable that. For mappers, the wide range of terrain tools and textures is so broad, you'll probably never need to download any community made tools. Only downsides are the outdated graphics, and the unusual controls. 9/10

where, oh where do i start. I'm going to try ad keep this as balanced as possible.

PRO'S
1.) the game is a decent game, but it gets boring fast (in my opinion.)
2.) has an amazing modding community which makes amazing mods that seriously enhance the gaming experience.
3.) Interesting control scheme which, once accustomed to, makes you 
4.) AI is quite difficult on some of the harder AI levels.
5.) Ability to increase the MP and CP cap is quite flexible and allows for very interesting battles
6:) very indepth in a good way. Able to direct control individual units 
7:) Basic inventory management (if you want to be reallllly inventory clean) but it isn't a necessity
8:) Visuals are okay, not completely terrible but it suits the game well.

Neutral 
Combat could be decent at times although there are alot of problems with AI (see below)
Ai pathing on some maps are very...broken. Some maps have slopes that should be passable and is accepted by the automatic pathing system, so units get stuck until direct controlled away from that specific area. (easy fix, spam mortars and fill the area XD )
Occasionally units ignore commands but its usually easily rectified by getting into the habit of spam clicking to ensure they don't ignore the commands
CON'S
1:) Just before we start with the negatives, the ai. It doesn't come with the game. To be able to have AI, for some reason the developers felt it reasonable to have to buy the airborne DLC just to be able to access the AI. The game should have AI already built in, not have it as a DLC. I feel like that is a seriously unfair money grab. In my opinion
2.) Seriously unstable. I like to play with bots when i play with my mate and we just generally try and have fun. The bots are certainly interesting but we'll cover that next point. Game frequently crashes for unknown reasons. Game frequently crashes for stupid reasons. Usually crashes because the programme is unable to create a dump file for certain files.
3.) AI Bots just spams things. Unfortunately for the game, the AI bots are thick as pigsh*t. The way the AI attempts to beat you is by spamming as many troops as it can at you hoping to do the Russian victory of overpowering with numbers.
4.) AI Bots sometimes breaks itself. Sometimes the AI just breaks, nothing spawns in or is unable to spawn anything in which means you have to go through the effort of going back to the menu and reloading the game, hoping that the AI doesn't break again.
5:) Learning curve is VERY steep at the start, especially when you have no one who is able to teach you how to play 
6:) the multiplayer. If you are looking for a multiplayer game that you play with randoms, i dont think this game is for you, if im being honest. Whenever i tried to join a multiplayer game i just get kicked. I just gave up with randoms completely and stuck to playing chill games with my mate.
7:) the editor seems complicated to use (or atleast i cant work out how to use it) i've watched youtube clips, read up on wikipedias and still cant work it out.
8:) lets cover the campaign, every countries set of missions is literally a reskin of the exact same missions. It seems the developers ran out of ideas for each campaign after completing the USA campaign. Would be nice for differentiating missions from eachother to show off what each faction could do. 
9:) I believe that this game is entirely centred around the multiplayer aspect only. It seems a lack of attention was paid to the the AI controlled bots. 
I seriously love this game but it seems to be waning fast. If you want to make your Bots a little smarter then i'd recommend getting the robz realism mod and getting the RobZ AI Fix, the game itself is beautiful in the way the battles are portrayed. i think i will continue playing just not as often as i used to

Absolutely Amazing Game. Together with a great community of modders, you can pour hours of micromanaging or spectating fun into it. Want great missions which take anywhere between 15 minutes and 4 hours? You got it. Want an editor to create any battle you want? Including Star Wars, the American Independence or Civil War, or special missions of your own country? Such as Australia, New Zealand, India, Switzerland? You got it. Want incredible historical accuracy? Small features around every corner? With this game, you can have your own new experience every time you play, such as direct controlling Dimitri #928384 and shooting a machinegun pill box with a pistol and getting a perfect DINK on their heads. At least for me, this is one of the best games on Steam, (along with ArmA 3 and CS:GO in my opinion) and I don't regret a minute of my combined 1000 hours in this game.

Men of War Assault squad 2 is an incredible rts strategy game with some incredible features. 

For those of you wizzing through the comment session here are the brief good/bads of the game and come things to note.

The good:
Realistic combat and physics
Equipment and vehicles are historically acurate
Multiple types of game modes
Tons of unique mods to use!

The bad:
Toxic and unforgiving community.
Texture on some vehicles and soldiers can be pretty bad.

Things to note:
If you enjoy taking you time in order to think and act out your tactics then you're gonna be in for a rough ride, success in this game relies on quick thinking and immediate action.
Even with a tutorial the controls are hard to get used to, but with time you should be able to use and understand all of the controls.
You should have some friends to play this game with...

So MOWAS is a great game and my favourite ww2 RTS game. That being said MOWAS 2 has one serious issue, the community. Holy hell, in all the games I have played the verbal abuse you get from players is vast and un-ending. When My brother and I bought the game, we completed all the campaign missions before moving on to multiplayer and we were pretty pumped to be playing with the community. However it didn't turn out well, people would kick us as soon as we joined and even if we joined and managed to stay in we would eventually be kicked later in the game. AND if somehow we weren't kicked in the middle of the game, the other players would spend more time insulting each other than actually playing the game. Some people just leave the game if it isn't going exactly their way. I'm not saying every player is bad, i'd say 1/10 game you can come across a polite group of players who can respect each other and enjoy the game. My brother and I gave up in the community and just stuck to private 1v1s and skirmishes, eventually we got a couple other friends to get the game and we enjoyed MOWAS 2 even more. All in all MOWAS 2 is an incredible RTS that's inhibited my it's testosterone filled, homophobic, racist and sexist community, best played with a friend.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is a slightly updated version of the first game. Most of its unique features, such as multiplayer ai or soldier veterancy, are locked behind dlc. The vanilla content should keep you and your buddies entertained for some time. However, the real reason I recommend this are the mods.

This game has GREAT mods. Mods that change the game completely (UWM40k, Cold War), games that make it more realistic (Robz, Great War) or mods that end an overwhelming supply of missions, scenarios and multiplayer maps (Valour). 

Assume direct control! In this RTS you can control a unit manually, aiming, deploying or driving as you would in an FPS. You can be flying an A-10, destroying a Russian armoured column. Charging with the Death Korps of Krieg infantry.  Aiming French howitzers and heavy mortars of the Great War. The versatility of this game creates its own genre of RTS dream fulfillment. 

All this being said, the game in its vanilla state is hard to recommend. My biggest problem is that the soldiers in this game also have no fear of death or morale. The maps are fairly small, and some the reduction of ranges to accommodate that can be laughable. The game lowering its graphics settings without your consent whenever your FPS takes a hit is also annoying in multiplayer.

Another thing I find bad about it is how you have to pay for the ''Airborne'' DLC to be able to add AI in your lobby, and the airborne parachute troops can only be paradropped in single player. There is no explanation for what the modes are so you have to figure out for yourself or google it and on certain maps there is cover that you cant place your troops behind, usually when you have a squad selected you can see the positions they would take when hover over a cover like a broken tank, sandbags or a building but some buildings/walls dont give you this option even though it would be game changing if you could get troops behind that one spot. Other than all of that i really like this game and it's accuracy to the second world war in terms of combat and units and the realism of it with projectiles, angles of hit, damage and the balanced gameplay and I would really hope for the devs to fix the server problems but until then i'll leave this as a negative review.

After that, it goes way down hill. German campaign is nearly impossible. The enemy just sends waves of units at you as if they are not effected by you taking thier points. That's okay, I like a challenge. Learned that setting up a good defensive line after taking some points is key.  However, the enemy can take you out with one hit while they remain untouchable. There is a armor penetration system based on caliber of shell and angle of impact. This would be great if they allowed you to build the correct AT cannons while they can role out top tier tanks. Otherwise, hope you can get a lucky shot off before the one-shot your AT units. Apparently Sherman Tanks are invincible, but German Veteran Tigers are gone in one hit.  Historically, that's bullsh*t. But whatever. Got to up the difficulty somehow , I guess.

I had this game for maybe 9 months before I gave it a solid go. The first time I tried the game, right after buying it, I wasn't too impressed. The visuals were really good, along with the soundtrack for the game - but I didn't spend a lot of time really delving into the game. So just recently I gave the game another try and after learning the the game some, it has turned out to be quite fun. One suggestion I would have for the developers is to add a tutorial with more detail. The introduction mission just throws you right into the action, which is all well and good - but on my first try, and being new to this specific type of game, I was left a little confused on where to go.

I really started gaining an appreciation of the game with the USA mission 'Bastogne' - you start with a small squad and that was the most helpful in really learning the in-s and out-s of this game. You can just throw units at the enemy, like the intro mission almost prompts you to do, but with some patience and application of a bit of strategy and tactical thought - you can turn a small squad into cinema-esqe heros! An introduction mission similar to that would go a long way with showing the depth of the game for new players. Blizzard was good with this in Starcraft and Warcraft; starting with basic units and putting the player in a position where the player needs to use all of the resources at the disposal of the small units to be successful/efficient. 

That being said - a new player might even want to give Bastogne a try to get a good feel for micro-managing their troops. Also a new player would really benefit from a controls based tutorial - I didn't realize for three missions that I could "slow" the game. This makes a dramatic difference. Perhaps it's just because the loading screens go by so quick on my PC that I don't get a chance to read them. The game performs and loads well, no crashes either.

One thing is could use however, is some refinement on issuing commands while the game is paused. I found it to be a bit buggy and either didn't issue orders properly when jumping from unit to unit, or at least it doesn't update the UI objects, like the mouse cursor and icons to confirm the order was accepted by the unit. The ability to slow the clock; however, does mitigate this pretty well.

The most annoying thing about the game is the in-ability to constrain the mouse cursor to a single monitor on a dual monitor system. There are some apps to 'fix' this, but it really should be an option in a modern game. 

In any event, this is a fantastic squad/RTS/tactical strategy game. If you play and really try to minimize your team's casualties, the battles can take some time - I find that to be a positive aspect as it allows for a high replayability level. I would highly recommend it for fans of squad-based/RTS games, especially for the price. Think of it as a mix between X-Com/Old Fallout/Baldur's Gate style games (due to the ability and almost necessity to micro-manage) and RTS like command and conquer or Total War.

I think I remember buying this game for about 5-dollars, and it's a good thing I did, because the experience is not worth more than that.

This game is certainly fun, and when you're feeling ambitious enough to try, it can be remarkably challenging. However, it is not what you should seek if you are pursuing anything more than a cookie-cutter tactical shooter.

The game boasts just over 50 missions, 10 for each faction of Germany, Japan, USA, UK, and Soviet Union. What it doesn't tell you is that each of the ten are identical. The first mission for the USA is identical in tactics and layout as the first mission for Japan. Move to X outpost, kill Y enemies, etc. The only change is the terrain and names of the units.

I have poured a fair amount of hours into the game; perhaps too many to complain that it's too simple, it's too repetitive, or it's too generic. But that's the honest part. The good news is, if you like tactical squad based shooters in the third person, this is a fun, cheap game that can scratch that itch...
...so long as you don't crave variety.

How a game of MOWAS 2 goes:
Russia as my country 
Train lots of infantry
Rush middle of map 
Lose all troops to 3 Panzers
Build AT squads 
Rush middle again and scare the shit out of the enemy tanks 
Loose 4 squads to destroy 1 tank 
Realise your Russian 
Build tons of tanks 
Activate “for the motherland” (literally spawns 10 squads of 9 AI controlled infantry to rush a sector)
Blast Russian national anthem through your speakers and move your 30 tanks to the front line
Result 
Your loss: 29 out of 30 tanks, all but 1 squad of infantry 
Enemy loss: 4 tanks 3 mg squads and middle objective 

Stalin looks calmly at his generals (in Russian accent) 
“ this was a great victory for mother Russia” 

(PS buy this game if you like strategy games)

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is better than Company of Heroes. There, I said it.

Before anyone cries river or condemns me of heresy, let me explain why. Men of War is an RTS simulation taking the simulation part extremely seriously. There is so much micro possible you wouldn't even imagine that it could exist in an RTS game. Tank plating efficiency for example is actually calculated by the factual plating at the hit zone and the degree of the hit, meaning that there can be grazing shots as well as cases where shells bounce off and then proceed to something entirely different. Maps have destructible elements on so many levels and it is possible to customise almost every single unit as well as loot AND immediately use any and all enemy equipment which wasn't destroyed. Including weapons, ammo, grenades, unmanned vehicles and any and all other support equipment.

This makes the game depths absolutely fantastic.

There is only one major grain of salt: The community is terrible. Like, League of Legends to the power of two.

When I first played this game, I was geniunely pleased. Even though the campaigns were mostly the same as each other, it was generally enjoyable.

But then I found the mods, the things that make this game 'better.'. And instead of finding great ways to enhance my experience, I was just met with incompatable files, crashing from said incompatible files, and a lack of any decent game mode that lets you fight the AI, a VITAL part of playing for a game like this. Unlike Arma, there is little to no way to change this and the only way to utilize mods to their fullest is to play with OTHER people, and the editor mode while existant, is very complicated for people who just want to play a scenario or a skirmish against the AI.

Despite the amount of mods out there  to use in this game, the lack of a vs Ai mode and the constant issues of mods being incompatible with one another has just ruined the entire experience for me. This game is NOT worth it unless you have a bunch of pals who play this game.

UPDATE: It's gotten worse. Thanks to the update, mods that fix issues such as a lack of AI, and most other mods in general, are now incompatible as the game now has a newer version. You have to wonder if the developers even want you to play the game anymore.

The best World War 2 realtime strategy game, with the worst community. Almost every online lobby (of which there are few) is hosted by a group of friends who tilt the odds in their favor, to make sure they can not possibly lose. They'll pick an unfair map, they'll screw with the game settings, heck some will even kick one or two of your teammembers once the game starts to ensure that they have a tactical edge on you. Basically, this results in four fifths of all games being pubstomps. I suppose their simple minds find "fun" in this. A pity.

Hosting your own game is a solution, but you'll be stuck waiting for players more than you will actually [i]play[/i]. Why? Because everyone's in the previously mentioned pubstomp lobbies, because most don't know any better. The few games that aren't totally teamstacked, are reasonably enjoyable. But why should a game only be fun a quarter of the time, instead of always?

While the base game runs fine, due to the 32 bit nature of the ancient engine, the popular mod RobZ (which adds a lot of units, and makes the game feel more realistic) has a tendency to crash. When it doesn't, it makes for a thrilling experience. Alas, between the crashes and the stacked teams, not enough of a redeeming factor to rejuvinate MOWAS 2 in 2018. Furthermore, it splits the community in half, meaning you get even less choice of who you want to play with. A shame, this would be one of my favorite games, if it had a more active, and less petty playerbase.

This game is brilliant in its aspect of large scale warfare but with the ability to control and position individual troops instead of you controlling an entire "squad"
It was actually rather beneficial too, because you could have a large force distract an enemy base or something, and send in one or two guys to crawl up to the defences and toss in grenades, then move the large force up as your surviving enemies flee from shellshock. You can approach most situations to your exact desire, and positioning is really important for victory. Occupied disabled tanks, hide inside buildings, charge trenchlines, parachute airborn infantry behind enemy lines, the way you do it is up to you. The experience is rich, and from what I felt challenging. Your guys arent invincible (unless youre on easy) but you can easily take the upper hand if you strategize well. 
I also just wanted to add that the multiplayer is really fun, especially charging through the campaign with friends.

Great game! If you’re a fan of RTS games - especially World War 2 games - then this is a must buy. Unlike a lot of other strategy games, where sometimes it feels rushed, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 lets you plan your next attack, move up your front lines (Whilst still holding off the enemy) and forces you to try out new tactics.

This could be clearing out enemy forces; street by street. Digging in and entrenching yourself in captured foxholes or trenches, overwhelming the opposing side with a large tank force or bombarding them with mortars to make room for your infantry.

The use of mechanics, medics, AT units and Flamethrowers units are key, as you will have repair tanks and other support vehicles, steal enemy tanks and use their own armour against them. Clear dense, wooded areas, revive wounded men (As all units come with a cost) and prepare for surprise tank attacks.

Attacks can be costly, so it’s always good to hunker down after capturing strategic points, whilst you build up for the next push.

One of the key aspects of this game is also taking direct control of your units - any unit! So rather than just pointing and clicking, the game allows you to get stuck into the battle - rather than just observing.
There is no RTS out there with realistic damage and vehicle modules, inventory etc. except for Men of War.

To be honest. It is a horrible mess.

I like the level of detail and the intensive micro management, the game has to offer. But is full of freakish bug, questionable pathfinding, stupid AI (when it is your units of course) and much more.

Want to jump over a wall? Forget it. Your soldiers are too dumb to accept the order. They want to walk around it and get shraddered by projectiles the enemy has to offer.

Want to refuel a tank? Go to hell. No fuel canisters under "Use item", no chance to refuel the stuff again.

Want to throw grenades? Are you stupid? Instead of being able to throw a grenade into a window or a tank (WITHOUT standing right in front of it), your soldier is begging for being shot as he has to run into the house via door instead of the window. These soldiers are stupid grunts and they let you know that.

They always do and walk around not like you have ordered it. They suddenly throw nades without you stating it, they walk, when they should run. They stay, when they should lay on the ground. They lay on the ground, when they should run away.  These soldiers are more stupid than any drone.

The games balance is good but as soon as you go above medium, it screws you. You can think of hard as something, were every unit has less HP and stuff and makes it difficult by giving you little time to do micro mgmt. No. The game decides to make the AI unfairly strong: They got more HP than you, they insta kill anything you put infront of it,  they have aiming across the whole map. Go. To. Hell.

In total, this game is no pleasent experience, as all those messed up gameplay elements make you angry.

I have over 400 hours clocked into this game and I'm literally still addicted. The game never gets boring, you're always learning new strategies and fighting skilled opponents in multiplayer. Not only that, but if the game does get boring for you, there are hundreds of well made, detailed, and polished mods on the workshop such as red rising, cold war mod, BITFA, robz realism, etc.. The editior is fun to fuck around in, whether it's making a custom battle, making your own map, or just trying to master some new infintry/armour skills there is always something to do. I don't see this game getting old to me any time soon. 


I'm sure a lot of dedicated community members would agree with me when I say this game is well worth the 40 dollars.

It's probably the most complex and historically accurate WWII RTT/RTS game ever made. Now, obviously, along with this comes a steep learning curve, it certainly took me a while to adjust. Never before have I had to worry about the amount of fuel in my tank, ammo for troops and so many different types of vehicles and infantry.

I came to this game a while ago from Company of Heroes and I didn't think that Men of War would be able to hold a candle to it. How wrong I was. I recently went back to try Company of Heroes after maybe a years break and it seems positvely arcadey now. The two games are quite different though and I don't think it's fair to do a like-for-like comparrison. I would say Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is more of a simulation experience.

Steam workshop is a great addition for mods but only a handful of them are worth considering. Most of the mods add additional units/teams, lower kill times (which are already short) and more unit effects (weapon jamming etc) but I would not consider them mandatory.

It's worth noting that I haven't tried any of the other games in the Men of War franchise but I didn't feel I needed to. The game looks good and runs (mostly) well on a moderate system with only occasional frame drops. I've mostly just played against a friend but recently we have ventured into the online scene and aren't looking back.

If you can get past the difficult controls and sometimes absolutely useless inconsistant AI, then you'll find an RTS with good pacing, lots of variables and replayability (based off the fact that it's kind of a sandbox RTS), intense and fun moments and realism. There's a lot of attention to detail in this game, the buildings being almost all destructable is incredible, and being able to burn bushes and having it spread to houses or tanks etc is very cool. The base system for armor penetration and unit inventory in general is more complex than most RTS's I've played. There can be a frustrating learning curve when figuring out how to deal with strategies, specific units, and the complicated direct control sequences you must sometimes perform to plant down an artillery unit, rotate it, aim it etc. It's a hardcore experience where you can lose games within a few mistakes, or even just a lackluster beginning. I think the fact that the game has some features in it that are DLC but should be in the base game is kind of whatever, since it was cheap enough to warrant buying them. I love the map editor but it can be super confusing and difficult to use, still not entirely sure how to make them playable in multiplayer but the option is definitely there, and games with level editors are always amazing in my eyes.
not worth all the money i spent on it and the dlc, but i had some fun with it regardless. don't get it unless you're cool with wasting money or the game is on sale.

I have no idea. You have to then individually select each unit and control it individually while the enemy are launching a massive multi pronged attack. Innevitably your strategy is reduced to almost nothing as you struggle with trying to get some commands out. Very realistic, no doubt. I guess I'm missing something big here. “You will get fucked so hard on multiplayer you will start to love it” -----  10/10 

Jokes aside, the Men of war series is a “hardcore” RTS, where mistakes are unforgiven and easy to make. The campaign is fun bud the multiplayer is the core of the game, it takes time and patience to start enjoying it. 
At first, you will hate this game to the guts and chimp out watching your troops being decimated within a split of a second, bud once you learn how the game works, it turns in to a challenging and satisfactory experience that only this series has to offer.
The game is all about making the most out from what you have, spending resources wisely and spreading your units with purpose. 
If you just brought it, I highly recommend that you go look for the “strat29” channel on Youtube before putting this game aside. It has some completive matches that will teach you a lot, and tutorials to get you started. 
It has many good mods on the workshop, and a decent amount of people playing online. 
The main problem of this game is that the players host the MP matches, and the HOST has way too much power, he can terminated the match midgame and kick whoever he wants with no repercussions even on rated games, and that will ruin a huge chunk of the matches you will play, so consider playing with friends and hosting the matches yourself so that wont happen, and if you do host, please dont become one of those guys...

I do recommend the game, but under certain circumstances. 

MOWAS2 is one of those games that falls along the lines of 'just playable enough'. It's biggest strength is it's engine's map editor and mod compatibility. MOWAS2 is like a badass war diorama where it's just fun to play around with the weapons and test things out. But.... that's kinda where it ends as the coneventional SP gameplay is super wonky thanks to an interesting game mechanic. The ability to directly control and aim the weapons of units and vehicles is awesome, but I don't want to have to rely on it. Well... it kinda forces you to use it, often. As great as the engine and concept of MOWAS2 is.... the AI at work here is ABYSMALLY bad. Most definitely an afterthought in the game's development. You will often find yourself HAVING to take direct control of your units as the AI often doesn't understand your command. Vehicle pathfinding is horrible and again you will often find yourself having to take control of vehicles to move with the WSAD keys as the ai can only understand simple movement. And for a game which claims to be more realistic than WW2 games like Company of Heroes, you're gonna have to learn to deal with the fact that.... units often can't shoot down from an elevated angle. Even non-fixed units like bazooka troops. They can't aim down. I know, I know, it makes absolutely zero sense. Sometimes your infantry acts intelligently and indivudally, and sometimes it'll sit there as a grenade cooks right by their feet. Maybe you'll get lucky in one of the rare occurences the ai actually picks up an enemy grenade and lobs it back at them. Who knows.... All I know is the poor ai makes the micromanagement(this game is super micor heavy) damn near impossible. 
The ai is SO BAD that the skirmish ai, often doesn't even work. You'll start up a match with the ai often to realize 5 minutes in that it hasn't even spawned in a single unit. Like why even put it in the game if it doesn't even work properly? I believe there's mods to fix that but come on... the devs should've taken care of that themselves. As fucking cool as MOWAS2 and everything it's presenting is... I just can't let the devs slide like everyone else. The ai is almost non-existant which in an RTS game is no bueno. It really does hurt the experience.
At least the MP isn't so bad. The mp gameplay is satisfying and often brings out the best elements of the game's engine. In MP you're given command points which limit the amount of units you can control at any one time. This makes the gameplay more balanced and tactical and it makes the overall micromanagement more possible. And the realism elements which actually work in this game, are pretty cool. Cause even in MP, the maps are almost entirely destructible. Every building you see can be blown up and levelled. The physics at work are actually quite nice.
All in all I still love and (sorta?)recommend this game. Just know if you're looking for conventional RTS gameplay it won't be found here and it's often better to look at the SP as more of a sandbox experience than anything else. And you still gotta give them credit where credit is due. Not everything may work properly but MOWAS2 sure is one ambitious RTS game.

A hidden gem!

Its been a while since I had fun with a RTS game. These days, RTS is less about strategy and more about quickly and furiously clicking like an epsorts match. MoW breaks that mould. Instead of using muscle memory and maximizing clicks per second, it requires you to carefully position troops, create chokepoints, sneak attacks, distractions and so on. Best of all, you can slow down the speed which allows you the time to actually play strategically rather than just furiously clicking a button.

The Single Player missions are pretty great as well. They is enough variation and complexity to keep things interesting.

The main downside for me was some excessive micromanagement in some aspects like reviving soldiers and restocking ammo. This can get tedious in a large battle where you have to find a medic and revive each guy who is about to die. I wish unit AI would do this on its own. Ammo resupply is also a chore. 

Still, I prefer it over whatever cheap click fest/ MOBA passes for RTS these days. It reminds of World in Conflict and Company of Heroes 1 which were both amazing. As Nick Cage would say, "that is high praise!".
Extremely fun game to play with friends, especially with mods enabled. The combat itself can be slow at times due to host internet connection, though it's a pretty rare thing.

Quite frequently, especially in buildings, soldiers don't fire even when they're facing the enemy. It's as if they need to be DIRECTLY faces enemy soldiers. They don't open fire even when they are diagonally facing. When soldiers are in buildings you have to move them when they're garrisoned in a building which can often result in them just running around and even accidentally moving outside into open fire. 
It's tedious that you have to position soldiers in exactly the right way to get them to open fire. Also, the artillery units don't seem to fire at tanks even when you order them to and, once you do, you're under fire by randomly spawning enemy units. These issues negatively effect gameplay in a big way.

Hello fellow Steamers, If you are here to check the reviews to see if its a good or bad game you are in the best place posible its called the reviews section(oh really?).

The game is pretty unique game that isn't produced on a large scale like first person shooters.
I will talk and summarize a bit about what the game has to offer and what's it lacking.

PROS:
-Very Historically accurate with its units. 
-The large and Detailed maps can give very different gameplays in each session.
-The Campaign is very broad letting you play 5 diffrent factions which include germany,
japan, Soviet Union, America and Great Britain.
-The textures and dynamic changes are numerous, You are able to plow up almost anything from buildings to the DAMN ANNOYING BICYCLES BLOCKING YOUR JEEPS(ARG, bicycles vs Armoured vehicle; Bicycle wins).
-Losing the entire battle when you forgot your units at the back that you ordered to come but wher stuck on bicycles.
-The workshop is huge and it has many missions and units to add e.g. Want too play italy or france there are enough mods, even china is added.
-Multiplayer battles are nice and quick paced lasting from 15 minuts to 45 minutes. 
-The community isnt toxic and really try to help you learn(do not enter Multiplayer right after installing the game the it turns toxic)

CONS:
-Multiplayer is slowly dying out
-Updates and patches are getting very few lately
-New players have a very steep learning curve
-Hanze always gets ze flammenwerfer.
-NEVER LET HANZ GET ZE FLAMMENWERFER.

Thats it i Hope you learned whats it about and if its worth your money:)

Some RTS games are great. They makes you feel like a commander supervising its troops on the battlefield, but none of them equals MOW2 in terms of micro gestion of your units. Every single soldier, gun carriage or tank of your army has an inventory , an hp bar ( elements for tanks like war thunder) and are fully playable in third person. Infantry is gonna be the backbone of your assault, from the simplest conscrits only equipped with rifles and anti personnal grenades to the armored division of elite warriors , who can put sandbags on the battlefield, have multiple weapon, an anti-tank gear, smokes, sometimes molotovs, flamethrowers, everything controllable manually with the mouse and the direction pad by the player. This two-sided gameplay ( controlling units with orders like any rts game and manually taking control of a unit to make sure a job gets done perfectly) is the second strong point of MOW2. If you wanna have spectaculary wars, where armies align douzens of infantry units and vehicles,  artillerie pieces, ressuply trucks.... play this game. 
If you wanna have sneaky skyrmishes, where every single sodat counts, and only one or two tanks are present, every action being a breaking point in the game, each player ressources being scarce..... play this game.
I recommend playing with the multiplayer mode first with your steam friends ( together vs ia or one against the other) , it brings you a great source of enjoyment while not being to strict for a new player. I haven't played enough of the campaign to say anything about it. 
MOW2 is in my opinion the best RTS i've ever had ( i played Starcraft, warcraft, age of empire 2, warhammer 40k dawn of war, company of heroes, command and conquer generals, wargame). Maybe you want to wait for the steam sold though, this game being pretty pricey for low budgets ( 36 euros with all dlc , summer 2018) but with -75% everyone should jump on it.

Good gameplay, good graphics. Lots of stuff to do with the game itself, from controlling a single guy throwing a knife or an entire platoon of tanks attacking the enemy frontline. Very flexible and allows for multiple strategies. 

Multiplayer is great, as is the Editor. Becomes even more epic with the easily accessible mods. Vanilla singleplayer is trash, cookie cutter "take these objectives and fight off counterattack" missions. However once again mods save the day.
