I love this series, I find the multiplayer to be extremely rewarding, but I have a problem. Four years after release, and the new, "faction," being added is just an expansion of the exisiting German army. Why can we get another nation to play? Italy, Hungary, Romania, France, Finland, China, the list of possibilities goes on. I want to see more diversity in this game. The only way to play any of the other countries that participated in the conflict is with mods, and mods break up the community into smaller pockets that don't play with each other. This causes a decline in players. Lately my average wait time for a 3v3 multiplayer lobby to fill up is about 20 minutes. 

Another issue is the toxicity in the community, because this game is so cheap on G2A and other sites, people have no problem making smurf accounts, and using them to stomp new players. New players get kicked constantly, as some people refuse to play with them on their team. So you have a highly competitve and exclusive environment that drives away new players and keeps the community from growing. 

As much as I love this game I can not recommend it in good faith.

Played it two or three days. Lets say it has a lot to offer, but for me personally, it was too much micro management to make it work, and i dont like to slow the game to keep track of all things. So, i decided to stop with it, it messes my brain more up then other games. 
If you dont mind micromanagement and fast decisions, you will love this game. Else its too speedy to cope, a lot of input. But the things i considered negative, others might view it positive. I can understand ii must be quite popular, but for me, more then i can chew on.

[b]PROS[/b]
+ Good RTS gamplay
+ Good amount of mods to keep you busy for a while
+ Has an editor (though not very intuitive, don't expect to make simple missions without watching tutorials)
+ Nice graphics
+ Really Good tank battles and strategy
+ Good amount of units in each faction
+ Nice mechanics

[b]CONS[/b]
- Abysmal AI for units (grenade in trench? let's jump out in machine gun fire!) made me rage quit
- Horrible copy paste campaign (each campaign for each faction is the basically the same, just different units)
- Have to pay DLC for bots in skirmish (total no no for RTS games)
- Really bad net code and not many people on multiplayer as a result
- Multiplayer isn't balanced very well (some units you should never buy)
- Bad fog of war

[b]NOTES[/b]
The game at it's core is really fun to play and has good strategy but it's really hard to enjoy with the terrible AI, though multiplayer isn't great either since servers are few and far in between and crashes a lot.

The fact that you have to pay DLC for bots in an RTS game is an absolute no no and isn't something I would like to see in the future whatever the price may be, with all this in mind I can not recommend this game to any RTS fan.

[b]CONCLUSION[/b]
Good game but plagued with horrible AI.

This game is very in depth and cinematic, while the UI is pretty ugly looking and cumbersome to start with, once you watch the tutorial videos in the bonus content menu you can have the game explained to you.  Units have inventories where they are able to scavenge weapons, ammo and other equipment from fallen enemies or allies across the battlefield.  While difficult, it is definitely a strategy game that requires a tactical use of cover, and the supporting fire from the right units.  With a mod community, this game also has the potential to turn into many different battle scenarios.

For a $30 game, I still really wish that this game had a hands on tutorial where the developers took you through a test mission.  This game has many tutorials and many small features that are easy to forget if you don't take hours just put toward LEARNING the controls as the tutorial menus are off of the main menu.

All in all, I have reservations about this game due to the learn it yourself tutorial videos, but I have no doubt that when I find the time between work to actually sit down and learn all of the videos, I will have money well spent.

If you don't have time to spend just learning a game and are looking for something to just jump into, this is not your game.  If you are looking for in-depth gameplay with realistic combat with consequences for failure then this is your game.

Two things first:
1) This isn't a strategy game. This is a tactical game.
2) If you don't like games where you can run out of ammunition and fuel, don't bother buying this. 

Pros:
+ Looks very good if you have a decent computer. 
+ The AI are never perfect in games like this, but this is by far the best I've encountered
+ In some of the maps you're pretty much forced to take the objective by storming the MG/artillery-nest, Hill 262- or Pointe-de-Hoc style. Even though you really care for your men, the mission comes first. 
+ Some really nice details, like the armor-placement on the MBTs. Don't try to hit the enemy tanks in the front, unless you bring some high caliber anti-tank guns.
+ The unique units each of the major powers possess' brings a lot of fun to the table.
+ You can't mass tanks and expect to roll over the enemy. Anti-tank guns will destroy your force. During urban battles the enemy infantry will use Woolworth grenades etc and take them out.
+ War is hell. At the start of the urban battles, you'll see a lovely small town. 15 minutes into the battle, and most of the buildings are either damaged or completely destroyed. PS: Use the buildings yourself, but don't put entire platoons inside. 
+ Everything that's left on the field, you can use. Fuel, repairkits, bandages, explosives, sand bags etc. If the enemy abandons a MG, take it. You can even repair enemy MBTs and use them yourself. 

Cons:
- Lost a soldier to artillery-fire, which normally would have removed his DNA from the face of the earth? Don't worry, a medic will patch him up in no time. 
- Can be a bit frustrating, especially when you try to control two-three advances at the same time. The computer always places the anti-tank guns etc at perfect spots. 
- Maybe some of the unique units are a bit overpowered? Especially the japanese artillery.

8.5/10.

Tl;dr: Recommended for people who like RTS style games and any of the following: World War 2, Mods, Tons of replayability, and a mission creating/ editing software.

Long Version: If you are the kind of person who likes Real Time Strategy games, this is the game for you. If you like world war 2 real time strategy games, this is most likely going to be one of your favorite games. If you dont like world war 2 games but still like real time strategy games, this game can be turned into a modern war RTS if you download mods. Basically, this game is for everyone who likes RTS games. With just the base game elements, no mods activated or installed, the game has a ton of content. You can play as: The Commonwealth (Britan/england/UK), The Soviet Union (the blyat bois), The United States (ameridudes), The Imperial Japaneese Empire (japan on drugs), and Germany (das waffen ss)
There are many gameplay mechanics and features in the base game. A list of these:
                Resources
Like many other RTS games, this game uses a resource system. The resource that you use is MP. I think it stands for man power, but i may be wrong. With the huge variety of units in this game, each of them cost different amounts. As an example, a small squad of inexperienced recruits may cost 50 MP, while a squad of battle hardened soldiers may cost around 100-150 MP. Even then, a light tank or armored personell carrier may cost 200-250 MP. Heavy tanks or Tank Destroyers may cost up to 400 points. And the most expensive units are special units. one such special unit is a veteran tiger tank,a heavy german tank with a battle hardened crew operating it. This costs over 500 points. 
                Units and Fire Support
There are tons of units and fire support types, its best to play the game and experience them for yourself.
>-Modding Section-<
 If you want the game to be alot more realistic, you can download many mods that enhance the game's realism aspects. One such mod i would recommend is Rob'z realism mod. The few things i noticed that changed or were added:
Added the ability for weapons to jam.
Added historically accurate armor thickness for vehicles.
And Made the weapons in the game historically accurate. (for the most part anyways)
These are just a few of many features of this mod. 
You can download missions for the game, and this just makes it even better


                                                             >>>CONCLUSION<<<
Just buy the game and experience it for yourself. Its not your average RTS, its not just another strategy game, Its not anything i have played before. This game is an experience, and a special experience that i couldnt recommend more than any other RTS in the world. However, i must say the soundtrack is a bit lacking for me, but thats just my opinion.
Just buy the game already, i dont know why you are still reading this. buy it and do whatever.

I bought Men of War: Assault Squad 2 in July of 2016. 

Sine then, I've logged over 220+ hours. That sounds low, but honestly it's not to me. I've very much enjoyed WWII simulations, and after seeing this game, I bought it as soon as I could. Since then, I've done a lot with this.

I love the editor mode, I like all the campaigns for the different nations. The different mods that I had put in: Faces of War, Bataille de France, Northern Hell, etc. They make an already good base game better. You don't need DLCs or even the above mentioned mods to enjoy this game, because the developers have already done great work with making a long assortment of missions across the various campaigns.
Definite recommendation.

I'd like to post this as a neutral, but that is not an option. 

I'll start with the good part. It's very indepth. In a good way.  You are able to control each and every member of a squad, the types of ammo used in a tank and even a bit of inventory management (if you so desire). But it's not required to paly. 

The visuals are ok, but they are not bad either. They suit the game pretty well.

Now the neutral part. Combat can be a lot of fun, but also a bit wonky at times. Units ignoring commands or pathing ai not being... smart. This is mainly on occasion and does vary when playing in MP matches.

Now the bad.
The game is clearly made with multiplayer at it's core. Which shows. The ai is dreadful, the campaigns pretty lackluster (every faction campaign is mainly a reskin of the same missions). Mission one is always defend a point, move up, a tank dies, go get it, etc.) Every single first campaign mission is this exact same formula. 
Another part is the fact that Multiplayer is very influenced by Latency. If there is one person with a bad ping, the entire game laggs out for everyone.

Now the worst part. The multiplayer. Over the past 10 hours (5 hours singleplayer) i've ran into 4 situations. 
The first is, just getting kicked out of a lobby. Join, say hi, get kicked. Over and over again. The second one is a lobby which is full, but you're stuck waiting because the host just isn't at his pc anymore. The third is finally in a game. Then getting owned by a pre made team of friends that actually coordinate, because someone apperantly forbid anyone from actually talking and communicating in game. (it's either russian or silent). 
The last situation, was that I was in a good game for once, pretty balanced. And a teammate just drops. He had a horrible connection, so the game suddenly sped up a bunch, but we were now down a player. 

Tl:Dr it's a game with some really nice details and combat, but is centered around a silent, unforgiving playerbase with the other option being an imcompetent and very lackluster ai.

I'm going to try the editor out now, if it's as fun as most people say I might give this a more positive review in the future.

This is honestly the best war game I have ever played. There are so many mods to keep you entertained from the Revolutionary war to modern-era to futuristic Star Wars it begins to make you wonder if this is some kind of battle simulator. If you play SP, it can get stale kind of fast, but MP is much better if you ignore how shitty the behavior of the AI is sometimes. To really have fun with this game, use the editor instead. There are tons of editor scenarios you can download that other people have created to keep you going forever. And if you get tired of that, learn how to use the editor and make your own scenarios. There is a good amount of info and various tutorials about the things that can be done in the GEM Editor on YouTube and on forums. Once you get experienced at making battles, then you can upload your maps/mission files to the workshop for everyone else to enjoy. Also, if you're a CoD fanboy, there are mods for you boys to turn this game into CoD.

My MoW:AS2 (Complete Edition) "review" as a solo player + player of the first Assault Squad. 
AKA: Things I like, things I don't in my singleplayer experience. 
FYI: Haven't finished the entire game yet! Still playing through! 

Things I Like:
- They've added new levels! At least, in the complete edition they have. Regular version, I'm unsure. But these new levels are cool and more than welcome. On some levels you can even choose when the assault should take place! 
- It's much easier to resupply things now! Previously, you had to resupply each individual inventory with supply trucks whereas now they have a radius around them in which units will stock up what they need automatically! Thanks for saving us time!
- The new levels add more variety to the game now. Something I didn't like was spending hours on one level, pushing forward through the 3 lines of 3 objectives just to be met by another right after. Now there are plenty of stealth and defence levels which are great!
- Some new units on certain levels you can deploy special units to help out (or in my case, create a more realistic battlefield) Officers for example! 
- They've improved upon the UI and graphics a little, adding more options and effects to the game. That said, my computer can't run this as well as the previous one but that's not saying much. My PC sucks. 
- You have a profile rank. So far, I'm unsure if you actually unlock anything from it, but I do like seeing that I'm earning xp. I think it's mainly for show in the multiplayer but you can earn xp in the singleplayer missions too!
- They've kept in everything I loved in the previous installment. I loved some of the old levels. I love reinforcing positions. I love moving up my line of forces and...well...I love this game too! But...


Things I don't like:
- It's Assault Squad 1, but with a few extra things. I'd expect more from a sequel and so should you! A few new levels...a useless rank system...persisting problems...no massive changes...no redone levels...no multiple looks for all those copy and pasted soldiers...more effort next time. This is just AS1.5...not AS2. Disappointed. 
- Choosing when the assault can take place: This is something I only just recently found and it's becase I went off the level and chose it from the menu. You can't do this with every map, which is fine, but had I have not went back to the menu and clicked on it, I would have completly played through the level/campaign without this feature. 
- Some bonus missions from the last game like the christmas one aren't here...what gives? You already have AS1 in here? Why not it's bonus levels?
- The leveling up is cool but you don't get anything from it. It kind of falls flat if I'm earning xp for nothing and I'm 10 hours in as of writing this and haven't notice anything change other than my level. Multiplayer players may appreciate seeing how experienced I am, but I don't play MP. Useless. Give us alternate uniforms/camos/unlockable units etc.
(The following problems still remain from the last game)
- Being thrust straight into the next mission: Completing this mission took me 3 hours. It says congrats, shows kills/deaths for each side, then gives two options. Continue playing the match or load the next level. NO! Give me something for slaying the opposition! Give me an option to go to the main menu and leave!
- I don't feel rewarded by completing missions as much as I should do: In the last 10 minutes of a possibly hour long level, you can just tell you're gonna win. All you get for that is a window saying congrats, with your losses and theirs and some Steam achievements. If I've killed 3 times as many of their units and destroyed 3 times as many of their vehicles, you'd expect more than that! I think this could be improved upon. Maybe a system of upgrades or unlocks for your faction. Maybe this is where they could add those Officers and shotgunners in. 
- Units STILL being locked to what mission you are on: E.g. There is a mission for the USA where it's more infantry focused, airborne to be specific. They allow you to call in officers but they aren't on every mission. I feel like they where more prevelent than some of these tanks. Imagine having more super heavy tanks than officers on the field. It would be chaos!

That said, this game is great..because it's the previous game, which was great...but with more stuff. 
I plan on playing a lot more. 
In the last one, I completed the USA missions and tried some of the Commonwealth and Russian missions too. 
I think I'll end up doing the same here. 

Anyway, if you liked Company of Heroes and maybe wanted more depth and a longer experience, or if you liked Commandos but wanted it on a larger scale, then I can definately recommend this to you! 
If you liked the last game and are ok with playing some old levels again to get to the new ones, then go for it. They're quite fun and different from the last game!
And if you're a fan of the snowy battles in Band of Brothers, I'm currently on a mission with a similar feel!

I really like this game.  To start off, if you're looking for a great single player story line,  you will NOT find that here.  All of the single player campaigns with different factions are extremely similar. I just wanted to get that out of the way. 

While i did say what i did above,  i still play this game solely for it's single player.  I don't play multiplayer at all so my review doesn't include an opinion on that.  What makes this game so different from other RTS's (which I usually don't like by the way), is that EVERY unit is an individual.  It's not like other RTS games where you have 10 infantry units all standing together,  but in reality it's just one unit,  the health for it slowly dropping and the "individual infantry units" dying one by one.  In Assault Squad 2, you can do so much more. 

 Let's say you have a normal infantry squad of ten.  Want to split them into two groups of five? Five groups of two? Send each  individual unit somewhere different on the map? Go for it! They are all individual units that you can do what you want with.  Here's another great thing.  Each individual human and vehicle has its own inventory. In it,  you'll see the weapons,  grenades,  ammo, and other tools they're carrying.  One of your soldiers run out of ammo? Loot bodies of enemies and comrades! A tank chasing your infantry? Didn't you kill an enemy with a RPG earlier? Go grab it! You can use the tools in the inventory to do things like plant or detect mines,  dig trenches to hide in or sand bags to hide behind,  heal people with medikits or bandages, etc etc. The list goes on.  

Also,  when combat starts,  it also feels different than other RTS games.  It's not always the case of the better unit draining the health of the weaker unit before it itself dies.  Cover and even luck matter in this game.  Your soldiers can take cover behind anything you would realistically think of taking cover behind.  Crouching behind a waist high wall,  back to a tree and peeking out to take shots,  lying prone in tall grass,  etc.  All of this makes it so,  for example,  three soldiers in great cover can take on a whole squad out in the open,  or make it take a good while to take the three soldiers down if the squad itself is in cover.  It can make a huge difference.  Also,  bullets miss.  A lot of the time.  Every shot doesn't hit every time.  Like I said before,  every unit is it's own individual unit.  That means every bullet shot is individual too. Just because 3 out of 4 soldiers missed their last shot,  that doesn't mean the 4th soldier has a higher chance to hit.  This opens up a world of possibilities instead of the stagnant better unit always defeats weaker unit.  Don't get me wrong though,  a better unit most definitely has the advantage.  Its just not as set in stone as in other games. 

Lastly,  what really keeps me playing are the mods in the steam workshop.  There are so many! They range from maps for single player vs AI and multiplayer,  mission packs for single player,  different skins,  even total conversions to make it look like the warhammer series,  or call of duty.  So much to choose from that I'm never bored. 

If the summer sale is still going on,  you can get this game AND the DLC for like 10 dollars total.  Even if not on sale anymore,  it's still a low price.  It's one of those rare games that you can keep playing for ages,  even just in single player. 

Call to Arms is the same kind of game,  only set in modern times.  However,  there's neither much single player content nor many mods to choose from yet,  so i focused on this game since it's a fuller experience.

TL;DR: More of a "mixed". Good, but loads of small or small-ish things that annoy me. I generally play it every once in a while, but am hoping that I'll find something better one day.

One thing that pisses me off is how they have modelled [i]loads[/i] of different units and vehicles, but you only get a handfull of them. Like, fighting germany the AI will send motorcycle-troops to fight you - but playing germany you don't get any. You get a Tiger, Goliaths (remote-controlled self-destruct "tanks" to blow stuff up), Pz. IIIs and IVs, King Tigers, Panthers, armoured cars. But no bikes, even though they'd be usefull for scouting. You also don't get 8.8cm flaks, unless in some defend-missions. And similar stuff happens with all sides.

Both you and the AI get cheats. There are 4 difficulties: Easy, normal, hard, and heroic. On easy, normal, and hard your troops get more accuracy, health, and faster reaction times than hostile infantry - on the other hand, the AI will greatly outnumber you, especially on hard and heroic. It is beyond me why they didn't just remove those buffs, and reduced the number of enemies.

Some equipment you can only acquire by calling more troops, some you only get a limited number of. Demolition charges you get one per vehicle, 2 per supply truck, and I think 4 per motorised infantry - but if you want to tear down houses, that's likely not enough. Would be nice to resupply those from supply trucks (which have a "supply" bar, which magically produces the right ammo to supply surrounding troops - great case of "gameplay over realism", would be a pain otherwise). Mines are hardcapped, and you only get the ones you have at the start of the game.

Some stuff gets resupplied, but only in very limited numbers. E.g. AT-guns get 5 HE shells. Want more? Put them right beside a supply truck, transfer HE shells into truck. Wait until the AT-gun is resupplied (takes 2-3s), transfer 5 more HE shells - if you want your AT-gun to be able to effectively fight infantry, you'll either have to do that for a long time, or transfer the ammo from a tank.

Friendly fire doesn't seem to be a thing, or greatly nerfed at least. The above-mentioned demo-charges can blow up pretty much all hostile tanks, but even armoured cars will rather be flipped than blown up if you're trying to blow them up yourself. Can lead to that armoured car ending up indestructable cover for hostile troops.



That said, there are still some pros to this game. The AI for troops is ok (and I call AI absolute shit in 90% of all games) - they will usually run from grenades and jump for cover, and if they get thrown through the air they'll run back to get their gun. Squads also share ammo between them. Now the AI is not great - e.g. your own AI won't automatically retreat if running out of ammo, nor acquire ammo or weapons from the fallen - but better than what I'm used to. The AI of hostile factions isn't good though, it just throws waves of troops at you - and gets infinite ammo, 'cause it can't handle resupplying stuff.

Armour is a thing - usually it'll take only 1-2 pens to take out a tank, even with low-calibre cannons (AT-rifles may take more). So really, the only thing protecting tanks is armour, not magical hitpoints.

Exact same game as the first Assault Squad with updated models/textures for tanks, working multiplayer(RIP GameSpy), and unscripted AI.
Singleplayer Skirmish mode, basically a free for all setting for use with mods, is locked behind the Airborne DLC, but multiplayer matches allow you to take advantage of facing bots alongside friends with varying limitations.

The singleplayer campaigns feel like boring filler, not giving you enough resources to make much of a push across the enemy lines - of course, when you do manage to make the best of your humble arsenal of light tanks and jeeps, the AI suddenly wakes up and floods the map with their heaviest tanks to absolutely overwhelm you.

Only buy the game for multiplayer, or shell out a bit more for the Airborne DLC for singleplayer modding.

I dont actually know how to write a review so Im just gonna do some pros and cons... (But the game is amazing)

Pros:
-Can equip your soldiers with other teams weapons. (This includes taking disabled tanks ammo and transfering it to your own tanks) 
-Soldiers arent equipped with 20k bullets (you actually have to resupply them)
-Your soldiers and other teams soldiers arent hard to kill (not 1 bullet = 1 kill but is close enough)
-No grenade spam (AI doesnt pelt you with them continually)
-Good modular damage for vehicles
-Good selection of vehicles
-Good modding community (Still active 2018)
-Good AI response (If you tell them to go somewhere they will)
-Amazing Editor (Can be difficult to learn)
-Anti Air actually targets planes.
-Para troops and air strikes are very pleasing to do.
-Nothing is really pin point accurate, except snipers, which make battles feel like a battle between soldiers rather than a ----battle between robot targeting systems. 
-Lighter vehicles manuverability is actually good and helps win battles. 
-Varying armor rating for diffrent vehicles (a sherman and a panzer 4 have diffrent weak spots and diffrent types of armor)
-Para dropping a squad to take over an objective is really cool.
-Individual units have individual ranks (xp and level ups are given to the soldier that got the kill, not the whole squad)
-You can equip a soldier with a .50 cal. Try doing that in CoH
-Destructible world. Want a building gone? throw some dynamite in it.



Cons
-AI pathing can be weird (Especially on custom maps)
-Micro-managing each soldiers ammo can be frustrating. (they do have ammo trucks tho)
-Ranges for weapons are wack: Most firearms can shoot somewhere in between 30-90ft. Some tanks with long barrels, like the m10 slugger, can be outmatched by an light German anti-tank cannon. 
-A lot of the singleplayer missions are defense missions that boil down to waves of tanks that get bigger as time goes on (There are 1 or 2 good defenses and the rest of the singleplayer is great)
-Its extremely rare but sometimes when soldiers are diving out of the way of a grenade they end up diving onto the grenade gibbing themselves.
-The Japansese kamikaze soldier is difficult to use. (Mods fix this)
-Flying a plane is incredibly lackluster. 
-Anti tank rifles do next to nothing.
-For whatever reason, tanks like to keep HE loaded even when they are fighting other tanks. 

In conclusion, the game is amazing. Its a lot more fun with friends especially when running the more fun mods. I dont regret buying the game and its still giving me fun after 2-3 years of having it.

This is a fun game and even better with mods.  

To address some of the neg reviews as I always read them to get a feel for what I am getting into.

1.  The tutorial is in the bonus mission and is called introduction, it is basically the first map of MoW A1.
2.  There are clipping issues, almost all games have some, you just notice them more here due to the maps and poor editing by the Dev.  Yes a true neg.
3.  I can not answer the clunky controls as I have played and own all of MoW games.  However, you can remap almost all of the keys to what you want and even macro some.
4.  I have not seen an AI soldier shoot through a building and one hit you, unless it was a bamboo hut.  If your trooper gets shot in the head he is dead, but most of the time they are not and can heal.  Plus if you have a medic you can revive almost anyone.
5.  Youtube has a lot of great information for new players, from basic fighting to full editing and making your own maps and missions.
6.  Workshop has a ton of great mods from Colonial wars to 40K and still people are making maps and mods.
7.  AI pathing sux plan and simple, there are mods that address some of these issues, but the original engine is the cause sadly.
8.  If you are not sure wait until it is on sale and get it, it really is a fun game and has a lot of replay value.
9.  The play style is not like CoH, you can only recruit units not build a base.

One of the best RTS's out right now, and in need of fresh players. Realism of units, physics and ballistics means that you actually have to take every rock, every bush, and every building on the map into account when choosing what forces to bring to a fight. A single infantryman with an anti-tank grenade can be a King Tiger's worst nightmare. One well-placed sniper can take out entire platoons worth of infantry. At the end of an MP battle or Singleplayer skirmish, theres usually nothing left on the map but craters due to artillery. Everything on the map is destructible. 

The game is brutal in MP, and there is a steep learning curve, however if you already play Wargame: Red Dragon/European escalation than you should have no problems picking it up. The game has assymetrical warfare; each faction has advantages and disadvantages. The Japanese have terrible armor, but the best anti-tank rifle in the game. The US has poor heavy tanks, but all riflemen carry semi-autos, while every other faction uses bolt-action. You'll have to learn these strengths and weaknesses and take them into account. 

I've found no RTS that is more tactically stimulating than MoW series. If you're new, I highly suggest beginning with single player to familiarize yourself with factions. Play Assault Zones against AI until you can beat one on the highest difficulty. It will take some time, and you will be scrutinized due to your low level when trying to find matches, but if you learn, it will become one of the most rewarding RTS's you will ever play. If you hate the MP, then get it for the fantastic singleplayer mods (Star Wars, STALKER, WW1 to name a few)

Call to arms led me to this game, as the game had free trial period. I like the game so much I decided to purchase the older game, Men of War: Assault squad 2, hoping it would be as fun or more fun

Man, was I wrong

[b] Pros [/b]

- It has some resemblance to COH 1+2 which happens to be game I have played and thouroughly enjoyed for many hours
- Many missions to choose from (as I bought the whole DLC package on sale)
- Enemies are somewhat sneaky, and constantly probing you for weaknesses, so you have to be vigilant all the time
- Decent graphics
- Lots of managing, if you are into that sort of thing 

[b] Cons [/b]

- AI is apocalyptically stupid. I have seen my tanks drive around and through enemies without firing a single shot. Basically every order you give is ignored as well. Makes you scream in anger and frustration, and subsequently punch a whole in your screen
- AI is blind as a bat. If the enemy doesn´t stand right in front of you, beggin you to shoot him, he is more or less out line of sight. Enemy snipers have taken many squads of mine cause the didn´t shoot back at a sniper firing at them
- Game seems sluggish. Sometimes it responds, sometimes it doesn´t. Like telling your antitank to fire rpg´s at tanks, take 3-4 tries. It becomes very frustrating after hours of gameplay
- Every mission is basically the same. Advance. Take points. Mission over. Zzzzz
- Enemy cheats. Several times enemy tanks shoot and kill me from outside the map, or from across the map as well. Furthermore some enemy vehicles are OP, and can kill my fiercest biggest tank in a single shot using a pebble on the ground

Overall the game seems very sloppy in design and execution, buy COH 1+2 wih DLC instead

For the life of me, I cannot recommend this game

Overall 10/10

Very underrated rts game that's shadowed by company of heroes. personally, after playing both of these games I believe that MOWAS is SIGNIFICANTLY, better. Each soldier in an infantry group can be manually controlled (and has his own name), different stats compared to the other soldiers in the squad, and has their own inventory, when you control a soldier you can manually pick up ammo off the ground, or switch weapons with another dead one. 


Compared to COH where the squad is just controlled as a blob, this game's a little more strategic. Manual control of soldiers, making individuals hide behind certain windows, pieces of rubble, in grass and other vantage points add a whole new level of strategy. Can't just rush squads in to points or tanks without proper recon, or support because a single soldier can take out your most powerful tank if he has dynamite, or a rocket launcher, and he could wipe a whole infantry squad if hes hidden in some grass and ambushes you.

Vehicle fighting is based on the parts of the tank you actually penetrate ( track shots detrack and immobilize, turret shots make it so you cant swivel, and engine shots destroy engine) Each tank has their own type of mm tank shell, and each tank has a different thickness of armor, depending on what it is each tank has its own weak spot. 

Multiplayer imo is where the game really stands out. The game's really competitive and theres kinda a pretty heavy skill gap between the vets and newer players. ( completely in the sense of micro management ) No advantage from being a higher level, just knowledge. If you're a quick learner, youll pick up the game quick and the tactics better players use, and what types of vehicles counter others, and for each scenario. (tank destroyers, AA tanks, light, medium and heavy)

TLDR: really good game, crazy amount of detail in micro management, can control a huge battle up to hundreds of soldiers while taking control of one individual tank or person to micro manage your fights, and VERY detailed tank combat.

I feel like there's a great game waiting just under the surface here. The effort put into the maps is amazing, and while the mission types are a bit repetitive then it's not like there was much Capture the Flag in World War Two anyway. However, every campaign has at least one, what I call "fuck you" point. When you reach the "fuck you" point, you're essentially tasked with breaking through an enemy line that is designed specifically to fuck you over. A good example is in the Normandy map in the US campaign. You break through the town and then you have open fields and a river to cross, you get access to air strikes (which are expensive and have a long cooldown) and paratroopers (which aren't much better than regular infantry and take a while after landing before they become selectable) but the German counter-attack involves seemingly endless infantry, tanks, stationary guns and possibly mortars. I don't know for sure because I can never find whatever it is flinging shells at me from miles away. On top of that, your soldiers have limited ammunition and if they run out then basically they're fucked (enemy soldiers do not run out of ammo, by the way), your tanks will always seem to move into the sights of enemy gun emplacements which -will- one-shot them even if your tank takes half a dozen shots before getting a shell on target and that's assuming your tank even decides to shoot at the one thing present that can fight it, but it won't, because fuck you that's why.  
  
With some tweaking for the sake of balance, maybe an enemy that didn't summon quite so many soldiers and tanks quite so often, and didn't get quite so lucky with its' artillery and field guns quite so often this could be a challenging, addictive  game. Instead it's just a grind. It's fine in intervals of an hour or so but if you find yourself bogged down then maybe set yourself the target of only doing the first half of any given mission because don't worry, you can select any mission from the very start from any of the campaigns, there's no restriction there. So go nuts.

Just buy the game.

Difficulty

There is easy, medium, hard, and something else that really hard.  Also you can turn fog of war on and off.

Prior Knowledge 

You really don't need to know anything about World War Two to play it I just suggest learning some tips before you first mission

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PUZg65KAMSk 

Mod Support

There is the steam workshop with plenty of good mods to keep you busy.  I would suggest Valour and the Cold War Mod.

Learning Curve

Not much really to learn just the basic game mechanics.  All I had to learn were the controls.

Content

There is are great missions included and you can play as, germany, japan, united states, commonwealth (UK), and my personal favorite the soviet union.  There are plenty of vehicles such as trains, tanks, cars, aircraft, and a few ships.  There are lots of differnet guns for soldiers giving each nation a different play style.  Did I mention there was a map editor?  Also there is multiplayer and AI if you want to play by yourself.

Price

During any major sale like the summer or Christmas sale you get 75% off so why bother with the original price.

My personal rating.

There are a few games I played that I think should get a rating above a 6, this game is 10/10.  It is the opposite of hot garbage.  Just buy the game.

If you have any questions please ask me.

Ok I love these men of war games……but why the hell are the Germans so bloody hard to defeat, first you cannot see the enemy tanks and they destroy your tank from nowhere, unbalanced unless you are German, artillery is useless but the enemy is just unbelievable…….enemy just keep spawning constantly it’s just ridiculous, units refuse to pick up guns unless you drop the weapon you have and even then still refuses to pick it up sometimes, flamethrower my fav unit but always set themselves alight after so long WTF.

Now play as the Germans….the Tiger was slow unreliable junk but fire power it was top dog…that is until you have control of it and lasts seconds before being blasted to crap what gives?

British 1943 Churchill tank had some of the thickest tank armor of WWII,  frontal armor had reached a staggering 6 in (152 mm) to the Tigers 100mm, while the minimal thickness (bottom) was raised to 0.98 in (25 mm), with sides up to 102 mm (4 in). Only the rare Tiger II and Jagdtiger surpassed it on this matter, the Churchill VII used the 75mm gun, and carried much more armor, 50% thicker at the front than a Tiger I, giving it the ability to withstand massive amounts of punishment…..so why does a Tiger take it out with one shot at the front or the Panther with a 75mm gun!

The Sherman Firefly was a feared tank to the Axis and yet it lasts seconds almost not even managing to fire a single shot, I’m sorry it’s poor balancing at best, maybe these idiots should do a bit of research first.
Fast becomes boring all this dying and restarting, this is why I can’t recommend it even though I love the game, shame really.

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is most likely one of the best WW2 games i've played yet. It features many locations significant to the actual battles, real factions, real vehicles and units, and to top it all off, spectacular gameplay, i never thought you could balance a game so well with reality and virtual gaming. The game offers many unique features, such as singleplayer and multiplayer, skirmishes, faction campaigns, and much more. The game dives into much greater depths with its individual unit features, as soldiers can run out of ammo; so they need to grab a gun off the battlefield or get more ammo. There are different unit classes, such as special units or elite units or just basic units. The multiplayer is incredibly balanced, with each character hosting a wide variety of soldiers and units at their disposal, this game is among my favorite to play in free time, It truly is the World War 2 Sandbox! Also did i mention it has Workshop support? Yea. Mods!

This game makes me feel like I'm 7 again, playing with legos and creating battles or scenarios in my imagination and carrying it out with a few blocky figures, This game brings that to life, just in a more age appropriate sense, The GEM editor is without a doubt, my favorite game, notice I said the GEM Editor, not MOWAS 2. MOWAS 2 is the tube towards the GEM Editor, easy to mod and create content for, but it all comes down to the creative power of the editor, which has stolen my heart. Don't get me wrong, the base game is good, I find it fun to play the missions on Co-op with some friends, but the editor is where it's at.

The GEM Editor is seemingly limitless in its abilities, I've created a plethora of a scenario, an ISIS ambush of an Iraqi convoy, IDF guerilla specialists fighting palistani insurgents, a U.S. marine platoons last stand against seemingly infinite japanese soldiers, I could go on and on describing what I've done with my time in thsi game, but I would like to see what you could do with yours.

This is game is worth every dollar

The learning curve is steep, the community is small and borderline toxic, the developer support leaves something to be desired... 

[i]Why[/i] do we still play?

Because there's nothing quite like it. [b]Men of War: Assault Squad 2[/b] continues what [b]Men of War[/b], and [b]Faces of War[/b] before it, started. This game is about micromanaging everything from each litre of fuel in your heavy tank to the amount of bullets in the inventory of your paratrooper. Each and every single asset on the battlefield has its' own inventory, which needs to be managed and resupplied. Each and every emplacement or tank needs to be protected, otherwise you're guaranteed to lose it. 

[b]Men of War: Assault Squad 2[/b] can make you feel like a tactical genius when you're doing good, or an absolute failure when you're grasping at straws to salvage a bad decision. The amount of gamechanging plays and subsequent comebacks that are possible in this game is nothing short of addicting.

I can recommend this game for those who have not previously bought all of the MOWAS type games from the developer. For someone new to MOWAS this is a very good game chock full of content, especially for countries that you cannot play in other RTS titles such as the Japanese units.  

The Japanese units are why I bought the game, and they have authentic voice acting (in Japanese exclamations and comments from the troops in-game, not the pre-mission English narrator of course) and the vehicles they have to play with are a good selection if slightly outdated in some cases where their units are literally 10 years older than the US equivalents.

The downside to this game is that the engine has always felt a little clunky. It simply lacks the "smoothness" you get in some other similar war RTS games. But on the flip side you can do much more with the units in the MOW series. Your troops can pick up inventory off enemy troops -- so they aren't just pre-built - if you want a flamethrower guy or to stea; an enemy tank you just make do with what's on the field. You can't do the same sort of thing in Compay of Heroes.

Overall a fun game but it has its flaws which for me are mostly in the engine itself.

Highly recommended if you love the original Men of War or Soldiers: Heroes of World War II. It has all the modernized graphical upgrades as Men of War: Assault Squad 2. You can also get the original MoW AS mission if you buy the add on, and it can be found inside MoW AS2 under bonus/extra missions.

Where to begin?



Men of War: Assault Squad 2, I’ll just call it MOWAS2, is the Arma of strategy games. Seems a little far-fetched at first, but there are some amazing parallels in between the two series. Decent single player campaign that gives you a good idea of what you are doing, multiplayer that’s relatively active, editor that can pretty much be your game if you learn how to use it, and a workshop page that is incredibly active.

I love the game, as you can see by my 600+ hours, but the fact is that it isn’t for everyone. 

The average multiplayer gamer won’t stick around forever for a good bit of reasons. The first being that the game modes are lacking to a certain degree. The game modes of multiplayer, just as any other game, get tiring after a while. Most multiplayer games end up in the same regard with the process of first contact->offensive->counter-offensive->repeat several times-> someone comes out as the winner. The game still has some balance issues regarding multiplayer, and the average gamer probably will be indifferent to the multiplayer overall. If you love WWII stuff to a certain degree, you will probably find multiplayer to be pretty fun, with the gameplay being more accurate rather than balanced.

Single player gamers can enjoy the campaign, but only so much. There are 5 sides, each with at least 8 missions, all with the premise centering around a modified multiplayer game mode, particularly the famous assault zones. The battles are spectacular at first, but the more you play the more you realize each mission is just reissued to another setting under another name. It gets boring after a while, but that is what the editor is for! 

If you have a good amount of spare time, take it and figure out how to use the editor. About 80 percent of the time im playing this game, it’s on the editor simply because of how limitless it is. With the scale of the game being so large, you can recreate the actual entire battle of Bastogne if you wanted to. And with the mods that the workshop can bring, it just makes the game all that much better. 

The actual gameplay is pretty f****** amazing. Again, people who are particularly invested in WWII games will appreciate this game more than the average strategy player. Then again, this is an epic strategy in scale, so the average strategy player will appreciate the MAJORITY User Interface.

The A.I. and micromanaging within the game is a slightly different story.

Each little infantryman has his own little inventory, name, kill count, and even a counter for how much combat he has seen (veterancy). But, managing this feature when it comes to a battle with 1000 men on the field is tough. This can come in to play particularly when repairing field equipment and vehicles. If you have a downed tank in the middle of a battlefield that can be repaired, it is a NIGHTMARE to repair said tank. You have to take a man, go up to the tank, look in its inventory, grab the repair kit, and then you can start repairing it. It sounds like a little issue, but the venerability that the infantryman owns when repairing that tank is very high, and the height of it comes when he tries to grab the repair kit. There are only a few little issues like this in the game. The A.I. can be bad at times, but doesn’t that just apply to most strategy games in general?

I have almost nothing bad to say about the graphics, pretty amazing in general. You will need a big computer to play this game at a normal pace. For how amazingly big the game is, the graphics surprisingly go beyond what you would expect in an Epic-RTS.

For those who love WWII games, strategy, and creating missions in editors (ex. Age of Empires) I encourage you to click that add to cart button.

For those who like strategy RTS games like Age of Empires and Command and Conquer, this is a little more complicated than the average RTS, but it can be fun once you get used to it.

For those who have never played any game in any category I mentioned, I really don’t know why you’re even reading my review, lol.

Sorry my playtime is not showing good enough for the reviewing but im writing it because of a problem we have here, and i played men of war years ago but brought it on the steam and started it again after the engine update.

[b]First of all lets look at the main game it self:[/b]

[b] + Extremely detailed on the small details[/b]
For the obsessive perfectionist characters, it may be a best. many details on everything, i finds some small details after hours of playing, for some people it may not be a big deal but for the obsessive perfectionist persons its sexy !

[b] + Its realistic[/b]
For example we have a 7 soldiers at the start, find out about the armored vehicle scouting around, if our soldiers havent a good stuffs for taking it out we can try to ambush it from behind by some granades, then the enemy's soldiers will leave it to try to run or use their hand guns to defend, take them down too and hide there bodies somewhere, find some repair tools and try to repair it if its not destroyed, then by put someone to drive and 2 more for the guns and leads its all fine and yours, yet we can carry more soldiers depends on vehicle but runing it without the supporters means we will loose it in the same way probably if not worst by the anti tanks and other possible dangers. its just one of the things we can do in this game.
Also im so glad this game have no digital neon marks around the fields or saint lights on the soldiers to show the owns and the targets, but we can find our lost soldier in the woods by the mini map easily

[b] + Its like a Chess Virtual Reality[/b]
Its not a turned base game but many of the "Strategy" games i played wasent actually Strategic but they had a grinding mechanism, gathering resources in the base, send a waves of units like a bugs, grow like a Mushrooms till capturing the whole map. these games are fun, perfect for killing time or meditation, no feeling for the units as the numbers and sizes are all the matter. but there are a few other kinds (and i think men of war kind started with the commandos and desperados) where the "Strategy" is the most matter, like in the Chess, even wen we have all the Chess pieces, at the start of the game with the one wrong step we can loose heavily, on the other hand with a few Chess pieces (unites) and wen the other side have much more unites, with some good moves we can win.

[b] + It have alot of hours content for playing and thinking[/b]
The campaigns of each side in the WWII from USA and britain to the soviet and germany, each campaign have a missions and mostly each mission will take a hour(s) to finish. also we have a multiplayer mode were we can play against each other or co-op with each other against AI.

[b] + System requirements & Performance [/b]
Simply it can run verywell & beauty on very old system, with the level of the details, with the nice special effects, i havent enjoyed this much from visuals in the others of this kind specially with the system it ask for run. no need to mention (as you know) today there are some visual novels and pixel games asking for the same system requirements, if not asking for heavier.

[b] + Good developers and publishers[/b]
As i said, this kind of games may started with the commandos and desperados and i loved them. yet Men of War developers not only tried to perfect this genre but they care for their child, they update the game, updated the engine for free and keep working on it. also i think it have a good price and good sale off.

[b] +/- recommended to who[/b]
Its not a game for the hack and slash lovers or other kind of fast paces, its not for having fun with rushing like a COD games in the isometric view, its not for the killing time, its a heavy game with the pure strategy needs, even it may not a game for the people who focus on just one game to finish then go for the next, but personally i think its a perfect game to finish one mission time to time between other games (like the Chess again), its not going to finish soon, it a brain sport for a long time.

[b] - Negatives?[/b]
I see many reviews used to be as [I like it or I dont like it] but im not ok with the personal taste reviews, i think the reviews should forcus on the technical and art matters. so in this case the thing i like to see more in this game (& these games) is more narrative and personality even by stupid conversations between the soldiers, as i said in this game the unites are not the bugs, they can die easy by one wrong step or do a great jobs by the good moves, still in this game we have a hours with a few soldiers in some missions and with some characteristic elements it can be more fun.

[b]And finally about the Problem of Assault Squad 2: Men of War "Origins"[/b]

[b]Its the remake of the First Men of War But...[/b]

There are some things about it is, and one of them made a problems.
One if these problems is, many people like my self cant put a review for the Origins as its standalone in the market and ask for a play time to allowing a review but wen i brought the Origins it become a DLC for my MOW:AS2.

So the thing is if you buy the Origins without having MOW:AS2, you will see the Men of War: Assault Squad 2 with the Origins DLC in your library but as you just brought the Origins, you have a Original Campaigns of Men of War.

If you have MoW-AS2, Origins will become a DLC and Plus to the campaigns into your rest of MoW-AS2 Campaigns menu.

So why if you just want the Origins, still you will get the campaigns in the Men of War: Assault Squad 2 menu in your library?
Seems the Developers/Publishers done it to make a better experience in the multiplayer/co-op, in this way the players who just brought the Origins can play with the people who have a Assault Squad 2 + Origins DLC.

About the different between MoW:AS2 and AS2-MoW origins, in short i can say Origins mostly have more missions like a comandos Missions were you have a few soldiers for a special missions but AS2 have a heavy Assaults mostly. 

For my taste, with the MOW:AS-CE + Origin i have all the bests in the series but [b]the Vietnam[/b] in this remastered package to complete my collection/selection.

I'm a huge Men of War fanatic, and this game was no exception.

One of the best experiences in my life was the time when i was only 9 years old and got "Faces of War" for my Windows XP. Since XP isn't that good of a computer, I only played FoW, and those hours I put into FoW were some of the best I could ever remember.

Then, 4 - 5 years after FoW's release I found the Men of War series, by the same developer and publisher, of course. When workshop was added to the game, it meant tons of more content from the fans, for example: Sir Hinkels AS2 missions, countless defense missions, countless assault missions, GSM (now deleted from the workshop) and many more.

9/10, would be a 10 if more people would play it, but for now if you don't have friends who play this game it will be hard to play multiplayer.

Pros:
- Highly tactical
- OK Graphics
- Historically acurate vehicle design
- Infantry can "strip" enemies and vehicles of weapons, ammo ect
- Enemy weapons (MG's AT) can be stolen by infantry or "towed" back by vehicles (ally weapons can as well)
- Units can be directly controlled for more tactical aplication of firepower (or if the AI is being retarded XD)
- All nations are playable from the start.
- Decent length campaigns.
- Individual infantry can be moved between squads to modify weapon loadouts.
- Two small squads can be combined into one with a single click/drag.

Cons:
- Very far engagement ranges, especially for tanks and AT guns
- Vehicles VERY vulnerable to AT weapons (often only two shots max is needed to destroy your vehicles)
- Infantry highly inacurate at med-long range (excluding sniper)
- Agressive AI has unlimited resources, ammo and fuel so a realistic atrition battle can not take place.

Short version: MaW:AS2 is everything Company of Zeroes wishes it could be but make no mistake, this game has discared virtually all arcade RTS elements in favor of a more realistic, simulation, style experience.

Men of War: Assault Squad 2 was a game recomended by a friend that took me pleasantly by surprise, despite me not being a RTS-crazy gamer. Going for a Company of Heroes-like economy, it saves you the hassle of base building and quickly brings players straight into the conflict. The game is pretty friendly to new and veteran RTS players alike due to it's simple Skrimish modes as well as the ability to play Co-op against enemy AI which I've spent hundreds of hours on.

On a tactical level, I quickly realized that many real-world concepts work here too; infantry works best in squad-level engagements, with MG teams covering an assault group, lone tanks or vehicles easily falling to sneaky anti-tank troops or even normal grunts with AT grenades, and the superiority of combined arms assaults. The immersion and environment sounds are simply amazing.

Replayablity is defintely a plus due to Steam Workshop compatablity. Community content allows players to set up their own missions, port entire campaigns from previous games and custom scenarios from other time periods such as modern warfare, hypothetical cold-War conflicts, other IPS (e.g. Star Wars, Warhammer, etc.) and I s#!t-you-not, the [i]American Revolution/Civil War[/i] black powder conflicts.

[h1][u] Pros:[/u][/h1]
[olist]
[*]Faantastic RTS gameplay
[*]Realistic physics and immersion
[*]Ability to micromanage to the individual level and even take precise control
[*]Realistic tank penertration physics on par with the likes of War Thunder or World of Tanks
[*]Lots of historical units, weapons and vehicles for WWII nerds to appreciate
[*]Sizable single-player content as well as multiplayer/co-op
[*]Mod support and great community content
[/olist]
[h1][u] Cons:[/u][/h1]
[olist]
[*]The voice acting, full stop (AIM IS IN THE REACH ZONE![?!?!?])
[*]Intense battles or certain mods may cripple framerate
[*]Very daunting to enter the mulitiplayer skrimish scene unless you have experienced buddies to show the ropes
[*]Occassionaly wonky physics (e.g, tanks getting stuck, resetting its position only to flip in the air upside down)
[*]Random crashes due to memory leaks
[/olist]

P.S. If on sale, it's best to buy the entire bundle with all DLC to save A LOT of money.

First off, let me begin by stating that I purchased the complete edition of this game when it was on sale for $10. If you already have the original Men of War: Assault Squad, I don't reccomend buying this game for full price. Wait until it goes on sale and grab the complete edition. 

Alright, now that I've gotten that out of the way, let me begin my review. 

This game is awesome, and for RTS lovers, a must buy. The detail is great and the options for battlefield tactics are unlimited. I haven't played a RTS that handles combat as well this does. If you're a Star Wars fan, get the Galaxy at War mod. It'll completely blow away the land battles in Empire at War. 

Lastly, this game runs very well on my laptop. I have a Nvidia GeForce GT 640M (1GB Dedicated GDDR5) and I'm getting 60+ fps with little action and 30+ when the fighting is heavy on medium settings. Overall I reccomend this game to all RTS lovers.
Awesome game!

I'm more on the fence than anything with this game, but there is no middle ground option. Seeing as that this game is $40, I'm glad I got it on sale...I wouldn't pay more than $20 for the Complete Edition. I like RTS, but this game doesn't meet my expectations as to what an exciting RTS is, but to each their own. My faves are Homeworld 1, Cossacks, and Battlezone 98 Redux for anyone else who has a similar preference and is wondering if they'd enjoy this. 

Pros: 
Great graphics. The amount of detail is superb.
Strategic gameplay, such as manually controlling where shots go. 
AI has some good tactics.


Cons: 
AI has unlimited resources, this makes combat dull as the victor has more firepower (tactics do play a part in this, until you remember your troops are out of ammo from the last fight). 
Routine find-destroy-repeat gameplay. 
No ability to build anything, such as barriers or bunkers for outposts, all you do is call reinforcements and use whatever is already set up. Mind you, you are limited to what you can call in, which is just annoying.

If you like RTS games, hardcore tactical Gameplay and a good challenge - go get it! I don`t know why this game does not have an overwhelmingly positive rating. Gameplay wise it is incredibly good. The atmosphere is always intense, there are no boring battles. You can manage your army to the last detail if you want to. Every vehicle, every single soldier has his own inventory and you have the freedom to manage every single detail of troops. By that you can turn a fight around even when you are totally outgunned, just by making the right decisions. It`s all about tactics/strategy. Only cons I have read so far is: it`s too difficult and units die too fast.  To the first I woul response: Get gut. To the second: how slow are you? I am no master RTS gamer by any means. But at least on normal difficulty your soldiers can survive quite long even being under fire from enemy infantry. But if you expect them not to be mowed down by an 20mm gun why bother with a realistic RTS game anyway and punish it for being realistic? Do you vote  a puzzle game down a because it has not enough hand to hand combat in it? The only con I can think of is, that your field of view can be a bit small at times and that you have to scroll around a lot  because of that. But apart from that, this game is just great!

TL;TR: realistic, hardcore tatctic RTS game. If you don`t like any of this, don`t get it. But if you do: what are you waiting for?

Amazing amount of realism.  There are enough missions to keep you occupied for hours and with the recent DLC, you can play against the AI finally in multiplayer.  This games requires more thinking instead of rush in and kill tactics.  You can control an entire squad, or a single soldier.  Tanks actually get damaged and do not take 10 hits to kill. This is the best RTS Steam has to offer right now. Initially I thought Wargame: Red Dragon was king, but Men of War: Assault Squad 2 completely trashes Wargame. Both are good, but Men of War pays more attention to detail. You can scavenge ammo from fallen comrades or enemies, and directly control a unit to do what you want. This is not possible in Wargame. Each and every single bullet is rendered until it exits the map. If a tank shoots a HE shell and misses, that HE shell might end up hitting a truck far way. You see an enemy tank camping behind a building? Direct control your tank, switch to APCR rounds, and shoot him through the building!

Get Wargame if you prefer fighting it out on a bigger scale, get Men of War if you absolutely love using infantry and tank tactics, and love to get down and dirty in door-to-door fighting on a smaller scale.

A Great RTS Game! I've played Star Craft, Command & Conquer and Empire at War; but this game tops all of them, it has a mediocre 'vanilla' campaign of the different belligerents of the second world war (The major Factions Eg. the USSR, Germany, Common Wealth, US & Japan). The mods on the workshop and the community made missions make it more versatile and engaging (Eg. Robz Realism & Valor). The Online community in multiplayer matches are fun to face off with, however check that you know the gist of the game before delving in head first, as it can be irritable for more knowledgeable players. 

- Great to play with friends
- Different types of Game Modes (Skirmish, Assualt Zones, Combat and Frontlines) Each with different attributes and challenges. 
- Can control individual units (Eg. Tank's in terms of angling, ammo selection and positioning)
- The Positioning of troops is important, as you cannot just rush through like a bunch of Zergs, but need to use the environment of the map to be able to either attack of defend successfully. 
- Realistic weapons ~ However there are mods that make the damages and the ranges more historically accurate. 

Overall A great game with great traits! When buying this game I would recommend purchasing the Men of War Origins DLC, that unlocks more missions and has a more engaging (less bland) campaign's than the plain 'Vanilla' Game. Do Buy it on a Sale as it's somewhat pricey when not. Its the Player that makes the Commander and skills are required rather than brute force. 

Ps. Key Think to keep in mind before playing this game, it can be very demanding in terms of controlling units and successfully upholding a defence or successfully attacking an entrenched enemy. Think outside the box in terms of units and their 'prescribed' uses and You will successful in the game.

On Steam Sale for super cheap so I figured why not? Turns out there are reasons why it's super cheap and that is a big reason WHY NOT. 

Somewhere in the patching (apparently) the devs managed to cripple the save system. Since buying the game I've been unable to get more than 3 minutes into a match without autosave killing the game. The only Dev support I've had has been a suggestion to "turn off autosave" which isn't actually an option anywhere. Not to mention that ANY sort of save causes the game to crash. 

I've done rollbacks to previous patches in the hopes that would fix the problem (it didn't), I've spent more time in long dead forums or trying a dozen different "fixes" that had no effect or were no help. I've basically spent a dollar per minute of ACTUAL gameplay and honestly, I want my money back. 

This is a trainwreck. Save your time and money and buy anything else.

Review for Steam awards.
If you are new to the series, and have patience, you are in for a great game.
If you are paying full price and you have previously played MOW:AS1 i wouldnt recommend the game.

I'm a massive fan of the series and personally have got my monies worth, but lately the dlc and subsquent rehashes of the game under a different name feel like a cash grab. It's painful for long term fans as, i'm sure most would agree, would love some more content rather than an era reskin and another game released for full price. 

AI was never fully finished in multiplayer (not a massive minus, but it was moved to a DLC!! absolutely terrible practice here...) but on the whole the game is QoL changes over Assault Squad 1. 

I'm actually updating this review as i've nominated it yet again for the steam awards. I'd love to see an assault squad 3 with a complete engine overhaul, probably hire the developers of RobZ realism mod too - that mod just takes this game to another level.

tl:dr if your into the multiplayer scene of the first game buy it, if your new, buy it on offer. If you played the first and didn't enjoy it... move along theres nothing to see here.

EDIT: This review was made before the shut down of gamespy so therefore it was obvious that we could just go back and play Assault Squad 1, however we can't do this anymore. So unfortunatly the multiplayer is still quite 'broken' in AS2 compared to predecessors. However they have improved it a lot since launch, for example you can manage to play a least a 2v2 now. 

I have always been a huge Men of War fan. I own and played every single Men of War released and never got tired of them. Even when people were dissapointed with Men of War Vietnam I still loved it.

When I saw a Men of War Assault Squad 2 coming out I was so excited. I already pumped 400+ hours into the first Assault Squad cause I loved playing it so much. When I got AS 2 and started to play, it was a disaster. The game only adds two or three new units and is a horrible remake of the original Assault Squad. Due to random lag spikes the game is barly playable more than a 3v3 in the multiplayer and lets not even mention the de syncs! Getting disconnected mid game is simply unacceptable for a full fledged game in 2016! With the new implemented idea of units needing to be unlocked once you reach a certain level makes the game unbalanced and unrealistic. Also the graphics are a tad better only for mainstream factions. For example, the Japanese vehicals look like they are ports from Assault Squad 1, same with a few other vehicals in the game, not retextued at all. 

I can guarantee this is not worth it's current price. Getting it on sale for $10 or under sure. Nevertheless, it is an alright game game, it has to be because it's the exact same thing as the first one. But overall, I don't know about you guys, but I wouldn't pay $35 for a reskin. 

Coming to a conclusion, I realize this game is a step in the wrong direction. The unit lock by levels, the auto resupply, the WAY overpriced DLC... it seems DMS is copying the ways of it's rival, Company of Heroes 2. We are losing what makes the Men of War franchise unique and this game shows it. At least we are not to far gone and can still make a return of the original feeling of Men of War.

This is proably one of the best and most fun games I've ever played. In terms of real time tactis and strategy it is quite superb. Phenomenal WWII amosphere, music, and details make the battlefield come alive. 

The gameplay is actually complex, if a bit on the micromanging side. However, after really getting to know the game, you learn how to use various soldiers, squads, vehicles and equipment and it enhances your sense of control on the battlefield. 

It takes time to learn shortcuts, commands, and various controls, but it's well worth and fun at the same time. The only major things that are essential to figuring out early is ammunition and perhaps direct control. Setting up soldiers in defensive lines is only as effective as what they're defending against and how mucht time they have to react. Certain "dug in" enemies and heavy armor are best dealt with personally. However, there are many possibilities to achieving victory and the game delivers a fluid, organic experience. Infantry need to be careful around snipers or heavy machine guns. Armor needs to watch out for AT. You can use environmental concealment and cover and use enemy equipment and vehicles guns as well. 

I keep coming back to this one. It is challenging and immersive.

PROS:

* Decent graphics
* Decent sounds
* Direct control
* Responsive gameplay

CONS:

* AI
* Bugs & Crashes
* Dated engine
* DLC paywalls for basic features, that cannot compete with similar features seen in even F2P games
* Explosion graphics could be improved
* Moderator abuse (banning people for minimal reasons and are taking baits from internet trolls while doing so)
* Ragequitters
* Singleplayer campaign is a joke (capture the flag on similar maps)
* Small and divided multiplayer community

CONCLUSION: The game is playable in its current state, however, I cannot recommend it at this point.

However, it has a fatal flaw: It crashes.

It crashes when you get a Steam notification.
It crashes when there's an explosion that's too big.
It crashes when you alt-tab.
It crashes when you invite a friend.
It crashes sometimes when you press the Multiplayer button.
It crashes sometimes on the multiplayer loading screen, even when finished loading.
It crashes ON THE F#CK|NG TITLE SCREEN if you leave it alone for too long.

"Debugging" was not in the developer's vocabulary.

(Please note that this is NOT due to a lack of RAM or hard drive space, I have 8GB RAM and over 100GB of free disk space, and the game never uses more than a few GB of RAM.)

This game is a masterpiece, in almost every aspect. Its engine is amazingly stable. The gaphics are stunning. The gameplay is in-depth, yet simple enough to be able to learn. I don't think that I have seen games outside the Men of War series, or the GEM engine that have mastered the simulation of warfare like this one has. Mods like Cod WW3, Star Wars Galaxy At War, and Red Rising are great testamets to how well made this engine is. The base game and mods like Robz Realism are great for the historian who wants to stir up a little carnage with their favorite tanks. It is quite spectacular. I would be a fool not to recommend this one. (I know that it's a carbon copy of the first Assault Squad but the engine is better and the amount of huge mods for it makes it well worth the $29.99, in my book.)

Oh boy does this game have a difficult learning curve. While positioning your squads or vehicles you'll definitely worry more about the AI doing wonky things that get them killed or do other facepalm-worthy moments as pathing can be terrible sometimes. 

The game is impressive in world detail, effects, and lighting. You can manually control (in third person) the AI and do the aiming/shooting yourself. The destructible environments make battles a blast to experience, win or lose. Tank battles are incredibly fun and you can lose a tank or two in the blink of an eye if positioned incorrectly, rolling up towards a hidden AT gun or facing a much more powerful tank. Tank guns have AT, HE, and various other round types to deal with specific threats.

I'm terrible at this game, to be honest and find more fun scripting large battles in the game's powerful editor which is, in my opinion, one of the best out there in the market. The sky's the limit when it comes to your imagination and the ridiculous amount of custom mods and maps in the workshop expand the game's longevity exponentially. So, consider this an alternative to enjoying your money's worth if you find the game too difficult or too much of a drag to play competitively.


===
Pros:
(+) Decent graphics that still hold up to this day
(+) Fully destructible environments
(+) Detailed hit mechanics for realistic and detailed tank battles 
(+) A huge variety of WW2 guns, vehicles, tanks and soldiers of various nations
(+) G.E.M.2 Editor for building your own maps, orchestrating your own battles and the ability to seamlessly transition from editor mode to gaming mode back and forth. You can even place more units during an ongoing battle.
(+) Workshop mods and custom maps.

===
Cons:
(-) Overall difficult gameplay: Damage values are realistic and soldiers each have their own inventory and ammunition to consume. As for vehicles, they have limited fuel and ammo as well. When playing missions involving a lot of units, it becomes a clusterfuck of micromanagement hell
(-) Outdated animations: The game still uses old animations from previous Men of War games
(-) Bad voice acting and soldiers sometimes say random unrelated things ("Quite unexpected", "Very suspicious!")
(-) Outdated Engine: Large battles and detailed city maps will gradually cause lag no matter how powerful your PC is.
(-) Wonky AI: Sometimes the AI responds to your commands to the letter, and sometimes they have a mind of their own. Remember to toggle the "Hold Fire" and "Hold Position" commands to ensure their complete obedience.

====
 7/10
====

I love games based around World War II and I believe this one hits number one for me!  The reason why I say this is because out of all the WWII games I have played, this has to be my favourite by far.  You get to pick what country you want to play as and control troops and armour.  Unlike other RTS games that the characters are large in comparison to the map (like a board game), Men of War makes everything the correct size.  When you run out of missions to complete you can add all sorts of mods to make the games feel different and enjoyable again.  You also recieve the map editor with the game that I believe is the true "GEM" of the game.  You get to create your own maps and publish them for others to play.  There is really limitless amount of options to do in this game!

I bought this game on a sale two days ago, been sitting in my wishlist for almost two years now. I had heard a few bad words about it, but from my personal experience, given the little time I have to play it, the game is very fun. All the micromanaging you have to do, keeping an eye on a units ammunition, setting up propper defenses, launching coordinated attacks on multiple points, keeping an eye on every little thing on the map to make sure that the boys make it home, managing your resources to have spare MP in case the other guy throws in somethingunexpected, these all seem so amazing and unique to me. I am not new to Strategy games or RTSs, but i've never seen such depth in any other game that I know of. Sometimes it can be a bit overwhelming but in general I see a game that every srategy lover would enjoy for many hours.

   I would recommend this game to strategy lovers but if you are looking for something less stressful and less complicated maybe this game is not for you.
